name: Aryan V S
full_text:
No wizardry required here... Apply context parallel on compute bound models for easy speedups. Oh, and don't forget flash attention 3!

Further, you can compile the model and set a few inductor flags for near perfect compute-communication overlap.

Don't want to use compile?
- https://t.co/9dUupSmA2k
note_tweet_text:
No wizardry required here... Apply context parallel on compute bound models for easy speedups. Oh, and don't forget flash attention 3!

Further, you can compile the model and set a few inductor flags for near perfect compute-communication overlap.

Don't want to use compile?
- Allocate the output buffers yourself
- Directly call into optimized cuBLAS with `torch.addmm`, `https://t.co/aY0JgNoaZ9`, `torch.addcmul`, `torch._addmm_activation` and similar
- Fuse memory bound operations yourself with simple triton kernels
- Wrap in cudagraph if memory permits

Want to go faster than FA2 and FA3?
- clone Tri Dao's repo
- shape specialize and extensively tune for your specific shapes ~ easy 15-30 TFLOPS for H100
- (BTW I've heard at least one person who's gotten a ~70-90 TFLOPS better BF16 performance with some numerical loss, but they didn't mention how and so I'm trying to figure it out myself lol)

The benchmark below is with Wan 2.1 480P 5 seconds, but 2-4 H100s with context-parallel should do the trick for Wan 2.2 720P 5s because it has a better compression VAE (16x16x4)

Code: https://t.co/ywrgL4PV1v

name: donald boat
full_text: @theo I won't solicit any more donations from you because I don't believe in turning this into any more of a spectacle than it already is. I can understand the concept of you making people smile vaguely, through a glass darkly. I can understand that you might have something that you
note_tweet_text: I won't solicit any more donations from you because I don't believe in turning this into any more of a spectacle than it already is. I can understand the concept of you making people smile vaguely, through a glass darkly. I can understand that you might have something that you consider a friendship in this world. I can understand that you might feel something like a thrill whenever whatever payment processing app you use clears another transaction. I just want you to understand one last thing, because I'll be blocking you after this. I have seen things that you will never ever see, feel, hear or touch. You are forbidden from these things for some reason that escapes me, because I am only a man and flawed in judgement. I won't suggest you kill yourself, because I have felt firsthand the pain of suicide transmitted even from orders of magnitude away and I believe in the dignity of man, something that escapes you and will escape you for the rest of your life. You need to wake each morning in a clean cell, make your bed with dullshiny white linen, and walk the halls of a cloister barefoot until you remember the feelings, sensations and small fears that even the most economically reduced man is capable of feeling. I want you to take the rest of the day off and focus on the steeplepoint of a local church, at the precise moment its apex is pierced by the light of our lifebringing star, and I want you to walk around with sunbleached maculae until your life is evening all of the time and you can rediscover from "first principles" what it is like to be a man.

name: Adam Zweiger
full_text:
Here are all the architecture tricks used by gpt-oss:

- Attention sinks - for each attention head, have a learned scalar such that softmax(qk) becomes softmax over [a_1, a_2, ..., a_T, sink]. Tokens don't have to attend to anything if all the attention scores are low!

-
note_tweet_text:
Here are all the architecture tricks used by gpt-oss:

- Attention sinks - for each attention head, have a learned scalar such that softmax(qk) becomes softmax over [a_1, a_2, ..., a_T, sink]. Tokens don't have to attend to anything if all the attention scores are low!

- Alternate between 128-sliding window layers and dense layers. This is the same as GPT-3.

- top-k MoE, with no shared expert and k=4. Standard load balancing loss.

- Really nonstandard swiglu - Uses œÉ(Œ±x) where Œ±=1.702 which makes the silu approximate a gelu. Clips gate activations to (-inf, 7], and up activations to [-7 and 7]. Adds 1 to up activations so final output is (up + 1)*glu instead of up*glu, which probably helps with gradient flow.

name: JingyuanLiu
full_text:
I am quickly going through the code: https://t.co/lj7NnVNN3V and found some personally interesting parts and manually ping  @YouJiacheng for any thoughts:

Some good details about Muon:
1. Dion is using MuP + Muon (so it is correct to use @jxbz  's spectral norm control rather
note_tweet_text:
I am quickly going through the code: https://t.co/m9nFpBL9sn and found some personally interesting parts and manually ping  @YouJiacheng for any thoughts:

Some good details about Muon:
1. Dion is using MuP + Muon (so it is correct to use @jxbz  's spectral norm control rather than Moonshot's Matching Update RMS), 
2. The readme claimed not to use nestrov, but the code by default uses nestrov. We should be using nestrov, I believe both Moonshot and Keller found that using nestrov is better
3. WQKV are separate, so it is practically better
4. The alltoall impl is good, avoiding the fsdpv2 dim-0 sharding as discussed in here: https://t.co/JB5HkQQzR6

Some parts I personally think can be even better:
1. MuP impl does not tune hyper-params of std and wd. It uses the spectral control init as described in https://t.co/4OtcQxVWu7 and https://t.co/KCIvPJvVcl , but that does not mean the std is set to \sqrt(1/d_in * min(1, d_out/d_in)). Instead another std and weight decay are still needed. The spectral norm control is designed for MuP transfer, but you still need to tune the hyper-params for a fair comparisons
2. the alltoall is not optimal, the momentum does not need to do the alltoall, instead, you could do local momentumn update first, then only run alltoall on the updated grad with momentum to save communication, like this PR:  https://t.co/gU1jhSGud4
3. A even better impl: you do not need the FSDPv2 reduce scatter for the last micro batch after bwd, instead you can hack the grad reduce scatter to be the alltoall in the optimizer step. as a result, you can further save one more communication. stay tuned, this is WIP: https://t.co/NSTpjd94Lu

reading more in progress lol... the code is clean and good to read!

name: Nate Chen
full_text:
Some have asked me how I learned Triton.

I didn't. I've read many tutorials (e.g. the official documentation) but finished none.

Instead, the more effective way for me is:
1. come across a paper
2. understand its algorithm 
3. read its Triton code on FLA (Flash Linear Attention
note_tweet_text:
Some have asked me how I learned Triton.

I didn't. I've read many tutorials (e.g. the official documentation) but finished none.

Instead, the more effective way for me is:
1. come across a paper
2. understand its algorithm 
3. read its Triton code on FLA (Flash Linear Attention github repo - it had lots of great & efficient Triton-based implementations and an active community!)

When I come across unknown Triton syntax, I can then search for & learn about them, which makes them more memorable. Reading the kernels for attention modules also provides new perspectives on understanding them.

name: leloy!
full_text:
I may have managed to reverse-engineer @Jianlin_S's soln

A couple of things to keep in mind tho:

1. msign(G - W @ sym(W.T @ G)) is only optimal for the square and full-rank case.

2. In some pathological edge cases, projection to the tangent space of W would already suffice. https://t.co/Y2LDNmQuHG
note_tweet_text:
I may have managed to reverse-engineer @Jianlin_S's soln

A couple of things to keep in mind tho:

1. msign(G - W @ sym(W.T @ G)) is only optimal for the square and full-rank case.

2. In some pathological edge cases, projection to the tangent space of W would already suffice. This might be the cheapest choice for most applications.

3. We can do newton-iteration-like corrections to the initial guess via solving the sylvester eqn, but it plateaus after only 2-4 steps

name: samsja
full_text:
My 3 favorites distributed/decantralized training paper. 

DiLoCo (obviously): Local sgd for the llm era, large batch size training https://t.co/ujjfsfV28f (from @Ar_Douillard )

DedLoc, system focus and first decentralized run ever of a an llm (in 2021) (https://t.co/co5xmdi2qH)
note_tweet_text:
My 3 favorites distributed/decantralized training paper. 

DiLoCo (obviously): Local sgd for the llm era, large batch size training https://t.co/Wq2F0i0mIn (from @Ar_Douillard )

DedLoc, system focus and first decentralized run ever of a an llm (in 2021) (https://t.co/I3UqVdPM73) from @m_ryabinin 

PowerSGD: https://t.co/tCe7HttLTj low rank compression of gradient without compromising convergence. Efficient implementation in pytorch, was used to train the first dalle 1 at open ai. 

This 3 paper are covering 80% of the sota imo.

bonus point for swarm parallelism

Finally, A survey of Deep Research!

This 95-page survey, from Zhejiang University, examines the rapidly evolving field of Deep Research systems‚ÄîAI-powered applications that automate complex research workflows through the integration of large language models, advanced information retrieval, and autonomous reasoning capabilities. 

They analyze more than 80 commercial and non-commercial implementations that have emerged since 2023, including OpenAI/DeepResearch, Gemini/DeepResearch, Perplexity/DeepResearch, and numerous open-source alternatives.

First chapter of ‚ÄúLet's Go Nirvana!‚Äù has been translated/scanned

Kazunobu Harumoto is a low-level member of a yakuza gang. One day, the gang's headquarters is attacked, and only he and the gang leader's young daughter, Mutsumi, survive. The police protect them by hiding them at Zenjoji Temple, a famous Zen temple with a history of over 700 years. What awaited them there, however, was a life of contemplation and ascetic practice.... name: Arthur Douillard
full_text:
NoLoCo: Gossip learning x DiLoCo = ‚ù§Ô∏è

NoLoCo (https://t.co/YnPwMQqEIa) from @gensynai proposes two contributions on top of DiLoCo:

1. Gossip: instead of waiting for a all-reduce between all DiLoCo replicas, make group of 2 at each outer step. 
* Communication is limited to that https://t.co/rHjlNlzMbR
note_tweet_text:
NoLoCo: Gossip learning x DiLoCo = ‚ù§Ô∏è

NoLoCo (https://t.co/ajDblARM3D) from @gensynai proposes two contributions on top of DiLoCo:

1. Gossip: instead of waiting for a all-reduce between all DiLoCo replicas, make group of 2 at each outer step. 
* Communication is limited to that pair, so basically doing gossip. 
* 1st term is momentum, 2nd term new outer gradients reduced within the local group of size n
* 3rd term is a regularization forcing the outer params of the group to be close
* 3rd term imply sending twice more data (!): outer grads + params, but luckily those params are constant for a  H=50 inner steps and thus can be fully overlapped
* it reminds me a bit of MoshpitSGD (https://t.co/Z7MgqMofuP)

2. Dynamic pipeline (somewhat reminiscent of SWARM https://t.co/cHnXJqtHWs) 
* where at each inner step, the different stages of the pipeline are mixed. 
* Cute but not really the main point of this paper.

Overall, very cool to see DiLoCo working well in this gossip learning setting, congrats to the NoLoCo authors! That's the most interesting paper i've read on distributed recently

Idk how well the baselines were tuned, the token budget is ok for 1B but too small for 6B. But they match or slightly improve over DiLoCo. Some things I'd like to see:
* Does NoLoCo behave better as the number of replicas scale? From table 2 it seems ~ as DiLoCo
* What's the perf without the 3rd term of eq (2)?
*  Very curious that optimal momentum for DiLoCo baseline was 0.3, so low! why?
* What's the perf of NoLoCo w/o dynamic pipeline? Fig 4. disabled the outer optim :(
* Even if it defeats the point of gossip, how do perf fare as the group size changes?

name: Arnaud Bertrand
full_text:
I'm normally not a fan of Piketty (what kind of person calls their book 'The Capital' but simultaneously badmouths Marx and says he "never managed really to read" the original "Das Kapital"?) 

But, credit when credit is due, this is a genuinely fascinating study.

It is in fact
note_tweet_text:
I'm normally not a fan of Piketty (what kind of person calls their book 'The Capital' but simultaneously badmouths Marx and says he "never managed really to read" the original "Das Kapital"?) 

But, credit when credit is due, this is a genuinely fascinating study.

It is in fact - somewhat ironically - the data-driven and unequivocal proof that Marx was correct when he said that capitalist wealth accumulation in Western imperialist countries was fundamentally based on exploitation and unequal power relations rather than fair market exchange.

Let's look through the paper.

First of all, a key value of the work is that Piketty and Gast√≥n Nievas (a PhD student) base their study on a new database that they put together (which you can access here: https://t.co/rCYWhDT6u6) that systematically reconstructs global trade flows and balance of payments for the entire world over more than two centuries (1800-2025).

This is genuinely groundbreaking work. No one - to my knowledge - has ever before created such a comprehensive database that tracks not just the "visible flows" of goods trade, but crucially the "invisible flows" of services, foreign income, and foreign transfers across the entire world - covering 48 major countries individually plus 9 residual regions that together achieve complete global coverage of population and GDP over more than 2 centuries.

What makes this database particularly valuable is that it allows us, for the first time, to see the complete picture of how wealth actually flowed between regions since 1800.

And not just what was officially traded, but the colonial transfers, tribute payments, "home charges" from India to Britain, debt impositions on Haiti and China, and all the other mechanisms through which the West extracted wealth from the Global South.

What the data shows is what everyone in the Global South knew instinctively but was contradicted by the dominant economic narrative: the West's wealth was built not through superior productivity or "free trade," but through systematic extraction, forced transfers, and colonial plunder on a scale that dwarfs anything previously quantified.

Take this extraordinary metric for instance: the authors' simulations show that a mere 20% increase in primary commodity prices over the 1800-1914 period, which the study says "corresponds to an absolute lower bound estimate of the value of unpaid forced labor in the export production of cotton, sugar, grain, etc. over this period," would have left Europe with foreign debts equivalent to 160% of its GDP, completely reversing global wealth patterns.

Put another way: had Western imperialist powers actually paid for what they took instead of extracting it through colonial violence and unpaid forced labor, the "developed" world would have been the "developing" world, and vice versa.

What‚Äôs also extraordinary is that this system of extraction very much continues to this day.
------------

Read the rest on my new Substack (link in next tweet)

name: JingyuanLiu
full_text:
Finally got a chance to learn @jxbz 's deriving muon and spectral condition, and I am AMAZED by the elegant derivation of how muP and Muon can be used together! In fact, it is natural to use Muon as the optimizer for MuP-based model training from the derivation. 

I would think https://t.co/1YdojiU9YL
note_tweet_text:
Finally got a chance to learn @jxbz 's deriving muon and spectral condition, and I am AMAZED by the elegant derivation of how muP and Muon can be used together! In fact, it is natural to use Muon as the optimizer for MuP-based model training from the derivation. 

I would think this is more exciting than Moonshot's Moonlight work of transferring from AdamW's HP to Muon via matching update RMS. While it is an empirically good heuristic, it does not take advantage of Muon's nature of 'controlled' spectral Norm for its update (updates from the msign/NS func), which is also an important property for muP to work by controlling the update spectral Norm to O(1)! 

I would be surprised if, by the end of the year, no tech companies scale the MuP + Muon. Basically, Jeremry already derived everything you need for a transformer...(Meta has MetaP, Moonshot is already using Muon, Greg is in XAI, and OpenAI hired Keller)

name: will brown
full_text:
i'm teaming up with @corbtt from openpipe to teach a class about agents + RL :)

we'll be teaching the class on @MavenHQ starting june 16. as far as we know, this is the first course of its kind anywhere to bridge RL + LLM agents, and we‚Äôre really excited to share some of our https://t.co/0ChDHO4Fah
note_tweet_text:
i'm teaming up with @corbtt from openpipe to teach a class about agents + RL :)

we'll be teaching the class on @MavenHQ starting june 16. as far as we know, this is the first course of its kind anywhere to bridge RL + LLM agents, and we‚Äôre really excited to share some of our favorite tips and tricks with you all.

both kyle and i maintain toolkits -- ART and verifiers -- for working with agents + RL, and the course will include coverage of both in different capacities, along with other popular agent tools (MCP, smolagents, etc). the goal is that you come away from the course feeling fully equipped to train your own custom agent models with RL.

the tagline pricing for the course is targeted at industry professionals. part of this is about managing bandwidth for facetime‚Äîthe course will be highly interactive, and we want to ensure we can accommodate everyone‚Äôs questions. however, we also want this to be very broadly accessible to anyone who stands to gain from a deep dive into the material. while we want everyone in the course to have at least some "skin in the game" to incentivize active participation + attendance, we are more than happy to give very steep discounts, particularly to current students / self-funded founders / independent researchers. email me at will@[‚Ä¶] with subject line ‚ÄúAgentic RL Course‚Äù and some info about your background and i‚Äôll get you a code.

as a preview, i‚Äôm teaching a free lightning lesson this thursday, may 29 (3PM PT) about building your own "deep research"-style search agent. we‚Äôll be doing a couple of these in the lead-up to the course if you‚Äôre on the fence, or just want a smaller dose of content. the course will be a useful structure for creating educational materials (notes, notebooks, etc.) that can be shared more broadly, for free -- maven's approach towards letting instructors own their materials while also offering really great course-hosting infrastructure was a key part of why we decided to work with them. more info below!

see you in class ü§ì

note_tweet_text:
After recording almost 50 database episodes, 50 Distributed systems episodes and talking to 100s of experts in the domain here are my top 10 Distributed systems learnings üëá 

1) If you can avoid having a Distributed system. Do it.

2) If you want to scale quickly, reduce the state and make your nodes as stateless as possible.

3) If you want to control reads and writes separately, isolate nodes handling reads and writes. Bonus: you can also choose appropriate hardware for each. 

4) Choose consistency over availability whenever you can.

5) If you want to reduce congestion, reduce contenders. Single writer pattern, Lock free data structures, Immutable operations etc can help. 

6) If you want to make reads fast, make sure you can use ‚Äúfast lanes‚Äù to fetch the data. i.e partitioning, indexing, caching create these fast lanes. 

7) If you want to make writes fast, use append only mechanisms and do all organisational tasks asynchronously.

8) If you want to truly isolate between tenants, use microVMs to ensure strong isolation with minimal overhead.

9) If you want to design a Cloud native system, build on top of cloud native systems, such as Object storage, k8s etc and don‚Äôt reinvent the wheel.

10) If you want to reduce complexity use first principles thinking and only solve problems that exist.

Bonus: Test as much as you can afford and use advanced techniques to uncover known unknowns and unknown unknowns as quickly as possible. 

Bonus++: Use formal verification to start thinking about complex systems in a simpler manner and uncover issues before they come to life. 

Please like and repost it. Also follow me as I am writing a detailed blog post series expanding on each topic with practical examples.

note_tweet_text:
As an addendum to what I discussed about the 2 types of serializability in the post üëá, let me add that Bernstein's book also describes View Serializability in the later parts of Chapter 2. Though his Serializability Theorem is based on conflict serializability.

He talks about View Equivalence and Conflict Equivalence and defines serializability based on these equivalences. And he states that View Serializability (VSR) is strictly more inclusive than Conflict Serializability (CSR) - and hence more difficult to prove. 

This is a grand unification of Bernstein's book and Papadimitriou's paper with respect to explaining the computational complexities of VSR and CSR. 

Here's a snapshot of the relevant section from Bernstein's book (the sidenotes are mine) ..

Self-Evolving Curriculum for LLM Reasoning

This paper, from Mila ‚Äì Quebec AI Institute and ServiceNow Research, tackles a key challenge in reinforcement learning (RL)-based fine-tuning of LLMs: how to choose which problems to train on, and in what order, for best learning and https://t.co/SQO4CzsssB
note_tweet_text:
Self-Evolving Curriculum for LLM Reasoning

This paper, from Mila ‚Äì Quebec AI Institute and ServiceNow Research, tackles a key challenge in reinforcement learning (RL)-based fine-tuning of LLMs: how to choose which problems to train on, and in what order, for best learning and generalization.

üöÄ The Solution: Self-Evolving Curriculum (SEC)

A fully automatic, online curriculum learning strategy that evolves during training, designed to maximize learning efficiency.

üß© How it works:

- Treats problem categories (by difficulty, type, etc.) as arms in a Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB).
- Uses absolute advantage from policy gradient RL as a proxy for how much the model learns from each sample.
- Continuously updates the curriculum policy via TD(0) to favor problem types yielding the most learning gain.

note_tweet_text:
I actually found MDP to be pretty straight forward after learning through examples

my intuition is that we have three simple states for a ball in a soccer game: it can be in the center circle, in penalty area, or in goal 

and from each state you can perform some legal actions: kick ball to the left, kick right, or score goal etc

each action _could_ lead you to the next state, but not always. you can score a goal from the penalty area but chances are, you miss and remain in the same state. that‚Äôs the intuition behind transition probabilities

and then if you make it to the goal you get a reward

This was my understanding from when I was learning MDP few weeks back:

note_tweet_text:
Photon is Databricks' C++ engine hiding under Spark SQL ‚Äî and the SIGMOD '22 paper is full of üî• for engine nerds. They explain:

- Why they ditched JVM for native code
- Vectorized interpreted execution (not codegen!)
- Runtime tricks like SIMD ASCII checks and UUID rewrites
- Benchmarks: TPC-H 4√ó faster, Q1 23√ó faster

Worth reading for the design decisions and a bunch of useful optimization techniques. 

Section 3 does a great job explaining design considerations and real-world tradeoffs. Sections 4‚Äì5 offer a collection of engine-level optimizations you‚Äôll want to borrow.

Excited to share new validation results of our @GoogleDeepMind @GoogleAI AI co-scientist!

Addressing the challenge of liver fibrosis, a condition affecting millions globally with few treatments options, we've been working with Dr. Gary Peltz @StanfordMed, exploring how https://t.co/ERAir0ubpS
note_tweet_text:
Excited to share new validation results of our @GoogleDeepMind @GoogleAI AI co-scientist!

Addressing the challenge of liver fibrosis, a condition affecting millions globally with few treatments options, we've been working with Dr. Gary Peltz @StanfordMed, exploring how co-scientist can help with identifying new therapeutic avenues for this complex disease.

Specifically, we tasked co-scientist with proposing novel hypotheses for epigenetic alterations leading to myofibroblast formation in liver fibrosis, suggesting new treatments and designing experimental protocols for validation. 

Towards this, the co-scientist uncovered and highlighted histone deacetylation and DNA methylation, pointing towards HDAC (like Vorinostat), DNMT and BRD4 inhibitors as treatment options for study in advanced human liver organoid systems.

Experimental validation by Dr Peltz's lab @StanfordMed showed HDAC inhibitor Vorinostat & BRD4 inhibitors had significant anti-fibrotic effects in the organoid models; further Vorinostat also aided regeneration and cut TGFŒ≤-induced chromatin damage by 91%.

We had previewed this work back in Feb but super glad to see comprehensive experimental validation results backing up the co-scientist generated hypotheses.

Notably, this work was done with an older version of the system from last year. 

We have made considerable progress building on the latest Gemini 2.5 models. More soon!

Bioarxiv - https://t.co/4dsI7mgeQu

AI co-scientist - https://t.co/fjdDVR1Phh 

Grateful for the collaboration with Dr Peltz's team at Stanford.

Work done with amazing team mates @GoogleDeepMind @GoogleAI @taotu831 @Mysiak @ckbjimmy @apalepu13 @alan_karthi @KeranRong @ynhnx and many more not active here.

name: Dan Roy
full_text:
This is a huge development.

I want to highlight the theoreticians behind the scene, because this paper represents the realization of the impact of years of careful theoretical research.

It starts with Greg Yang (@TheGregYang) opening up research on the muP scaling and
note_tweet_text:
This is a huge development.

I want to highlight the theoreticians behind the scene, because this paper represents the realization of the impact of years of careful theoretical research.

It starts with Greg Yang (@TheGregYang) opening up research on the muP scaling and hyperparameter transfer in infinite-width models. Simultaneously infinite-depth scaling are studied by Boris Hanin (@BorisHanin), Mihai Nica (@MihaiCNica), Mufan Li (@mufan_li), and Soufiane Hayou (@hayou_soufiane), including in networks with residual connections. 

Then this builds further with the study of infinite-depth scalings and Transformers by Lorenzo Noci (@lorenzo_noci), Blake Bordelon (@blake__bordelon), Mufan, Chuning Li (@ChuningLi), Hamzat Chaudhuri (@hamzatchaudhry), Boris, and Cengiz (@CPehlevan) in at least 3-4 papers, in particular using the DMFT framework. 

My understanding is that the translation of these insights into this work was highly nontrivial and so congrats to Cerebras for seeing it through with this great team.

I also think this work could serve as a wake up to those in industry who reacted to muP saying "yeah yeah yeah we ended up at effectively the same place through careful scrutiny". I‚Äôd love to know which labs landed here, if any. If not, it goes to show you cannot have everyone grinding code. You need fundamental research to fuel BIG leaps.

note_tweet_text:
Very excited about our paper. 

I've been working on this problem for 8 years. When I started end-to-end self-driving was controversial. Now we're the first to show that on-policy training in a world-model simulator can create agents that are useful in a real-world product.

This is not demoware. The driving policies in the paper were all shipped to public openpilot, and were used by real paying users for months. 

The robots feel a little bit more alive every day.

Core steps to get started:

1. `ùóΩùó∂ùóΩ ùó∂ùóªùòÄùòÅùóÆùóπùóπ ùó∞ùóÆùó∫ùó≤ùóπ-ùóºùóÆùòÄùó∂ùòÄ`

2. Choose the action space, load database and `oasis.make()` to create the social media environment

3. `env.reset()` to start the simulation

4. Simulate agent actions and `env.step(action)` to let agents post, like, and interact

5. `env.close()` to end the simulation

Social Simulations with LLM agents have never been easier! üöÄüöÄüöÄ

name: TNG Technology Consulting GmbH
full_text:
Today we release DeepSeek-R1T-Chimera, an open weights model adding R1 reasoning to @deepseek_ai  V3-0324 with a novel construction method.

In benchmarks, it appears to be as smart as R1 but much faster, using 40% fewer output tokens.

The Chimera is a child LLM, using V3s https://t.co/3HYtHSLwF7
note_tweet_text:
Today we release DeepSeek-R1T-Chimera, an open weights model adding R1 reasoning to @deepseek_ai  V3-0324 with a novel construction method.

In benchmarks, it appears to be as smart as R1 but much faster, using 40% fewer output tokens.

The Chimera is a child LLM, using V3s shared experts augmented with a custom merge of R1s and V3s routed experts. It is not a finetune or distillation, but constructed from neural network parts of both parent MoE models.

A bit surprisingly, we did not detect defects of the hybrid child model. Instead, its reasoning and thinking processes appear to be more compact and orderly than the sometimes very long and wandering thoughts of the R1 parent model.

Model weights are on @huggingface, just a little late for #ICLR2025. Kudos to @deepseek_ai for V3 and R1!

name: Damek
full_text:
lecture 13: scaling transformer training (an overview of @huggingface ultrascale playbook)

1.  intro: huge transformers need distributed training (model/activations > gpu mem). 
2.  bottleneck & fix: activation memory during backprop often limits scale. activation recomputation https://t.co/fcC4vrU4tq
note_tweet_text:
lecture 13: scaling transformer training (an overview of @huggingface ultrascale playbook)

1.  intro: huge transformers need distributed training (model/activations > gpu mem). 
2.  bottleneck & fix: activation memory during backprop often limits scale. activation recomputation (checkpointing) saves memory, trades for compute.
3.  start simple: data parallelism (dp) replicates model, splits data. good first step, but memory-bound by largest replica.
4.  model > memory? use fsdp (zero-3). shards params/grads/opt_states across dp ranks. essential for fitting large models.
5.  layers/activations > memory? use tensor parallelism (tp). shards *within* layers. cuts activation mem, needs fast interconnect (e.g., nvlink). increases comms.
6.  combine: standard is 3d = fsdp (data/state) + pp (layers across nodes) + tp (layers within nodes). beyond this: seq parallel (sp) refines tp mem; context parallel (cp) handles long sequences; expert parallel (ep) manages moe models.
7.  link included to visualize dp/fsdp/tp activation flow & comms!

name: Aram HƒÉvƒÉrneanu
full_text:
Some interesting languages you might not know about (links below, sorry).

1. Unison

Haskell-like language where references work by hash, not by name (sort of like de Bruijn indices, but with hashes). Names are but separate metadata.

This is facilitated by the source code not
note_tweet_text:
Some interesting languages you might not know about (links below, sorry).

1. Unison

Haskell-like language where references work by hash, not by name (sort of like de Bruijn indices, but with hashes). Names are but separate metadata.

This is facilitated by the source code not being stored in text files, but in a structured format.

There are no merge conflicts, and you can pass closures to different machines in the cloud. Unison uses algebraic effects.

2. Effekt

A much, much simpler take on algebraic effects than the standard one, and an exercise that shows that sometimes less is more. In Effekt, functions are second class, which sounds alarming at first, but in actuality it behaves like a normal functional language. You don't have to give up much.

3. Flix

Another functional language with algebraic effects (this time with a more traditional take on effects). Flix has first-class Datalog constraints, which make it quite unique. Flix puts a lot of effort into tooling and developer experience.

4. Hylo (formerly Val)

An imperative, zero-cost abstraction language (like Rust, but much simpler) that's based on mutable values (as opposed to references). References in Hylo are second class. It uses coroutines for traversals, which make iterators possible even with second class references. Graydon Hoare likes this language.

I'm only barely scratching the surface of these languages in my descriptions. There's much more to them than that. I hope you'll check them out!

This is my attempt to explain algebraic effects to systems programmers.

note_tweet_text:
This is my attempt to explain algebraic effects to systems programmers.

An effect is like a system call, and an effect handler is like the kernel code that handles the system call. After the user process issues a system call, the process is suspended, but the kernel can resume it, while also passing a result back to the process.

Algebraic effects are like this, except generalized outside the kernel. The kernel is no longer privileged, you can have any number of handlers written in userspace.

I've been hacking on a super simple AI assistant: built with a single SQLite table of memories and a handful of cron jobs, hosted on @ValDotTown.

The assistant is called Stevens. Every morning it sends a brief to me and my wife via Telegram, including our calendar schedules for the day, a preview of the weather forecast, any postal mail or packages we're expected to receive, and any reminders we've asked it to keep track of. All written up nice and formally, just like you'd expect from a proper butler!

Here's an example. (I'll use fake data throughout this post because our actual updates contain private information.)

Beyond the daily brief, we can communicate with Stevens on-demand‚Äîwe can forward an email with some important info, or just leave a reminder or ask a question via Telegram chat.

That's Stevens. It's rudimentary, but already more useful to me than Siri!

Behind the scenes

Let's break down the simple architecture behind Stevens. The whole thing is hosted on @ValDotTown, a lovely platform that offers SQLite storage, HTTP request handling, scheduled cron jobs, and inbound/outbound email: a perfect set of capabilities for this project.

First, how does Stevens know what goes in the morning brief? The key is the butler's notebook, a log of everything that Stevens knows. There's an admin view where we can see the notebook contents‚Äîlet's peek and see what's in there:

You can see some of the entries that fed into the morning brief above‚Äîfor example, the parent-teacher conference has a log entry.

In addition to some arbitrary text, entries can have a *date* when they are expected to be relevant.  There are also entries with no date that serve as general background info‚Äîyou can see these particular background memories came from a Telegram chat, because Stevens does an intake interview via Telegram when you first get started.

With this notebook in hand, sending the morning brief is easy: just run a cron job which makes a call to the Claude API to write the update, and then sends the text to a Telegram thread. As context for the model, we include any log entries dated for the coming week, as well as the undated background entries.

Under the hood, the "notebook" is just a single SQLite table with a few columns.

But wait: how did the various log entries get there in the first place? In the admin view, we can watch Stevens buzzing around entering things into the log from various sources:

This is really just some data importers populating the table:

- An hourly data pull from the Google Calendar API
- An hourly check of the local weather forecast using a weather API
- I forward USPS Informed Delivery emails containing scans of our postal mail, and Stevens OCRs them using Claude
- Inbound Telegram and email messages can also result in log entries
- Every week, some "fun facts" get added into the log, as a way of adding some color to future daily updates.

This system is easily extensible with new importers. An importer is just any process that adds/edits memories in the log. The memory contents can be any arbitrary text, since they'll just be fed back into an LLM later anyways.

Reflections

A few quick reflections on this project:

It's very useful for personal AI tools to have access to broader context from other information sources. Awareness of things like my calendar and the weather forecast turns a dumb chatbot into a useful assistant. ChatGPT recently added memory of past conversations, but there's lots of information not stored within that silo. I've written before (https://t.co/NfzmAgEIKV) about how the endgame for AI-driven personal software isn't more app silos, it's small tools operating on a shared pool of context about our lives.

"Memory" can start simple. In this case, the use cases of the assistant are limited, and its information is inherently time-bounded, so it's fairly easy to query for the relevant context to give to the LLM. It also helps that some modern models have long context windows. As the available information grows in size, RAG and fancier approaches to memory (https://t.co/PZx6xZsekg) may be needed, but you can start simple.

Vibe coding enables sillier projects. Initially, Stevens spoke with a dry tone, like you might expect from a generic Apple or Google product. But it turned out it was just more *fun* to have the assistant speak like a formal butler. This was trivial to do, just a couple lines in a prompt. Similarly, I decided to make the admin dashboard views feel like a video game, because why not? I generated the image assets in ChatGPT, and vibe coded the whole UI in Cursor + Claude 3.7 Sonnet; it took a tiny bit of extra effort in exchange for a lot more fun.

Try it yourself

Stevens isn't a product you can run out of the box, it's just a personal project I made for myself.

But if you're curious, you can check out the code here (https://t.co/L9Cq8PnN0P).

If you want to explore, it's probably easier to just take this idea and run with it rather than using my code. You should be able to apply this basic pattern‚Äîa single memories table and an extensible constellation of cron jobs‚Äîto do lots of other useful things...

name: Rudy Gilman
full_text:
The sdxl-VAE models a substantial amount of noise. Things we can't even see. It meticulously encodes the noise, uses precious bottleneck capacity to store it, then faithfully reconstructs it in the decoder.

I grabbed what I thought was a simple black vector circle on a white https://t.co/eK7ZtLJ6lc
note_tweet_text:
The sdxl-VAE models a substantial amount of noise. Things we can't even see. It meticulously encodes the noise, uses precious bottleneck capacity to store it, then faithfully reconstructs it in the decoder.

I grabbed what I thought was a simple black vector circle on a white background but the VAE latched on to a veritable Navajo quilt of background noise. I was absolutely flummoxed until I realized what was going on!

A lot of capacity being used on things we don't need to be modelling at all. Suspected culprit is group norm.

note_tweet_text:
The Software Internals discord hosted by @eatonphil is such a gem.

Today, I'm learning about non-cryptographic hash functions from someone who personally knows many of the field's key figures and is also contributing to the state of the art. So cool! ü§ì

What makes RotoHash special:¬†
- Simple design - just uses 3 operations xor, rotate and one round of AES encryption
- Elegant example of leveraging hardware capabilities for maximum performance (AVX2, AES-NI, etc)
- Claims higher quality than related non-cryptographic hash functions based on SMHasher3 test suite

name: Byron Alley
full_text:
The upcoming Elixir Phoenix 1.8 release looks awesome

* UI tweaks
* Simplification
* Security upgrades

Lots of things I've wanted are there:
- DaisyUI
- Magic links
- Light/dark mode
- Scopes for resources
- Layout organization improvements
- Pub/Sub generated for resources https://t.co/NPioZpKCZW
note_tweet_text:
The upcoming Elixir Phoenix 1.8 release looks awesome

* UI tweaks
* Simplification
* Security upgrades

Lots of things I've wanted are there:
- DaisyUI
- Magic links
- Light/dark mode
- Scopes for resources
- Layout organization improvements
- Pub/Sub generated for resources (with LiveView)

After reading the latest announcement I created a few test apps to check out the changes...

## Scopes

*Scopes* are probably the biggest deal.

Resources should almost always be scoped to prevent IDOR and similar security issues. You need to scope at least to resource creator/owner and often you have an organization, group etc. that it belongs to.

So without scopes built-in, you're going to gradually create an ad-hoc version. I've done this a few times. It's just tedious and sometimes awkward.

Now when you run `mix.gen.auth` you create a Scope which applies to future resources you generate. 

Generators that used to give you list_items/0 or get_item!(id) will now create scoped function like:
- list_items(%Scope{} = scope)
-  get_item!(%Scope{} = scope, id)

## PubSub

PubSub is already nicely built into Phoenix, but now the LiveView generator will build the PubSub into the Context module directly and into the LiveView.

Say you have a ToDo app: every ToDo item that's CRUDed will broadcast the change, and LiveView is generated to subscribe on mount and react to changes.

It's all stuff that was never hard to write yourself, but it's good to have this built-in as a pattern.

## Security

Aside from the move to magic links, I also see improvements to the docs and code comments explaining security concerns.

## UX

There are a bunch of little things that aren't so little, like having light/dark mode just built in, and DaisyUI now officially "part of" Phoenix.

## Simplification

The way Layouts work makes more sense now, but I won't get into it -- it's explained pretty well in the blog post.

Similarly it's good there's been an effort to simplify CoreComponents although I didn't delve deeply into that yet.

name: Haibin (on leave)
full_text:
We are open sourcing bytecheckpoint and veomni! 
bytecheckpoint is the Bytedance's production checkpointing system for foundation model training, battle-tested with jobs with 10k+ GPUs. Blazing fast save/load, load-time checkpoint auto-resharding for different parallelism across
note_tweet_text:
We are open sourcing bytecheckpoint and veomni! 
bytecheckpoint is the Bytedance's production checkpointing system for foundation model training, battle-tested with jobs with 10k+ GPUs. Blazing fast save/load, load-time checkpoint auto-resharding for different parallelism across training stages (pretrain/SFT/RL). 
veomni is a open source model training framework for llm and multi-modal training. UI-TARS (the SOTA GUI Agent model prior to OpenAI operator's release) is trained with veomni. Developed with modular design, integrated with sequence/expert/zero-optimizer parallelism, offloading optimizations, @liger_kernel. Trainer-free (let user control the training loop) and easy for researcher to hack! The go-to framework for text/multimodal llm pre-training and post-training, from research to production.

Try them today, your feedback is welcome!

Code:
- https://t.co/IKM7ceK7GN
- https://t.co/HAzL6Omc6j
Paper:
- NSDI paper: https://t.co/HjHgbjv9r0

name: leloy!
full_text:
I'm not sure if someone has already pointed this out, but Dr. GRPO still has a bias that is more pronounced the smaller the group size is.

To make it unbiased, simply multiply Dr. GRPO's A_i by the correction term N/N-1. With this, you'll get LOOP (Leave-One-Out Proximal Policy https://t.co/VDk2QlciaW
note_tweet_text:
I'm not sure if someone has already pointed this out, but Dr. GRPO still has a bias that is more pronounced the smaller the group size is.

To make it unbiased, simply multiply Dr. GRPO's A_i by the correction term N/N-1. With this, you'll get LOOP (Leave-One-Out Proximal Policy Optimization). And if you also remove PPO's clipping, you'll get RLOO's (Reinforce Leave-One-Out).

name: Nathan Lambert
full_text:
A very exciting day for open-source AI! We're releasing our biggest open source model yet -- OLMo 2 32B -- and it beats the latest GPT 3.5, GPT 4o mini, and leading open weight models like Qwen and Mistral. As usual, all data, weights, code, etc. are available.

For a long time, https://t.co/S0HMk3Ll9o
note_tweet_text:
A very exciting day for open-source AI! We're releasing our biggest open source model yet -- OLMo 2 32B -- and it beats the latest GPT 3.5, GPT 4o mini, and leading open weight models like Qwen and Mistral. As usual, all data, weights, code, etc. are available.

For a long time, people have asked for an truly open-source version of ChatGPT and we finally have it. This is multiple years coming into efforts following the release of ChatGPT and builds on the efforts of so many at both Ai2 and in the broader open AI ecosystem. 

With just a bit more progress everyone can pretrain, midtrain, post-train, whatever they need to get a GPT 4 class model in their class. This is a major shift in how open-source AI can grow into real applications.

Oh yeah, it's also Apache 2 as always, so happy to make things that are simple to use. I did NOT expect to be undercutting OpenAI's offerings this year but here we are :D

name: leloy!
full_text:
People doing open-source work are cool by default

However, I don't find this result informative mainly because:

1. The original GPT2 arch is a weak baseline; and

2. It seems the hyperparameters weren't tuned

---

I've also noticed a couple more implementation details that
note_tweet_text:
People doing open-source work are cool by default

However, I don't find this result informative mainly because:

1. The original GPT2 arch is a weak baseline; and

2. It seems the hyperparameters weren't tuned

---

I've also noticed a couple more implementation details that make the baseline weaker:

3. The GPT2 baseline doesn't have learnable attention scales while the nGPT model does. This is a problem because not having learnable attn scales induces an upper-bound on the sharpness of the attn logits and thereby a lower-bound on the attn entropy. This constrains the model's ability to "attend" to important tokens during training.

4. The GPT2 baseline has weight decay while the nGPT model doesn't. And the weight decay for the baseline (Œª = 0.1 w.d.) may be too high for the model size (0.5B). This induces an upper-bound of 1/Œª = 10 on the singular values of the params and thus limits the expressiveness of the model. And

5. The GPT2 baseline uses the same learning rate as the nGPT model despite having activations of different "sizes". This may not actually be a problem in the end, but it's best to tune the LRs, other things, separately for each model.

---

And:

6. Given that nGPT is 10% to 17% slower than baseline, a perf-by-flops comparison would also be very helpful.

---

IMO it's best to:

A. Use a much stronger (SOTA) baseline like the one we have in the NanoGPT Speedrun https://t.co/TLiQiAjzoi and/or

B. Parametrize the models (both the baseline and nGPT) such that we can do hyperparameter search on a smaller scale first (let's say with 150M params & 10B tokens) then "transfer" the learning rates and other hyperparameters to the original, larger scale.

until then, nGPT will stay in the model arch purgatory

---

I actually see these kinds of issues a lot in published papers, sometimes even from bigger labs

Aside from misaligned incentives, I think another big problem is that we don't have an established & universally agreed process for comparing model arches. Every lab and every paper have their own process. It sucks.

It would be cool to have a Model Scaling Tool of some sort where a student from some random school can just implement their model arch idea, run the tool, then get small-scale results & hyperparameters for larger-scale versions of the model in case they want to scale it up.

name: Qian Li
full_text:
This paper proposes co-design and co-optimization across the entire stack for modern OLTP engines‚Äîfrom the top-level client and application, through transaction models and query execution, down to the operating systems.

Some interesting research directions:

1. Bridging the gap
note_tweet_text:
This paper proposes co-design and co-optimization across the entire stack for modern OLTP engines‚Äîfrom the top-level client and application, through transaction models and query execution, down to the operating systems.

Some interesting research directions:

1. Bridging the gap between applications and databases:  What is a better transaction model that balances security, performance, and ease-of-use? Interactive transactions remain the most common pattern but suffer from high communication overhead due to roundtrips, while existing stored procedures are difficult to use and security risks due to insufficient isolation.

2. Bridging the gap between databases and OSes: Modern databases often bottleneck on network communication. Interestingly, even for disk-based DBMSs, the network stack overhead remains a critical factor‚Äîaccounting for 45% of CPU cycles in Postgres when data fits in memory. For faster in-memory databases, the network overhead is even more significant. This paper highlights the need to explore kernel bypass optimizations for both the server and client sides (the latter is often overlooked).

Looking forward to more research in these directions. I especially hope to see more databases prioritizing user experience while exploring better performance!

name: Didier 'Dirac's ghost' Gaulin
full_text: There are many great introductions to logic for both mathematicians, analytical philosophers, computer scientists and logicians out there, many which I have recommended in the past, but since I have discovered recently the SML series by AMS, I had to check out A First Journey https://t.co/RhadpfyXT5
note_tweet_text:
There are many great introductions to logic for both mathematicians, analytical philosophers, computer scientists and logicians out there, many which I have recommended in the past, but since I have discovered recently the SML series by AMS, I had to check out A First Journey Through Logic, by Hils and Loeser.

This is a nice little package, which interestingly starts with order theory, in a chapter titled ''Counting to infinity'',  often neglected in logician texts or explained extremely formally, for example in Jech' Set theory. 

The second chapter introduce you to First Order Logic, in a style reminiscent of van Dalen's Logic and Structure, with a nice sub chapter on semantics and substitutions. It also contains a nice explanation of Godel's completeness theorem, a result which is essential to your understanding of modern logic. 

What I also enjoy about modern text on logic, like this one, is that they also take the time to introduce model theory, which is the case in chapter 3. Computer scientists will appreciate the inclusion of recursion theory, in a well written short chapter, and also a nice excursion into arithmetic models and limitation theorems.

You also get an interesting explanation of Godel's first and second incompleteness theorem, and although you might want a more specialized text if you really want to get into that subject deeply, it's still a pretty little condensed way to get around the idea.

The book ends on axiomatic set theory, which occupies quite a few pages of the book, with a few of the more advanced results explained, such as the generalized continuum hypothesis. 

This book is not focused on proofs, and when they are presented, they are made clear and not over formalized, which I find important for a beginner's text. If you're a teacher, this might be a good one to use in a class.

name: Junxian He
full_text: When we were working on the "compression represents intelligence linearly" project (https://t.co/rhnHzrM6iq) months ago, we found that models' compression efficiency on some documents is more reflective of the their downstream abilities than other text.  Since then, we have been
note_tweet_text:
When we were working on the "compression represents intelligence linearly" project (https://t.co/baUoPdHTRa) months ago, we found that models' compression efficiency on some documents is more reflective of the their downstream abilities than other text.  Since then, we have been thinking of using the same intuition to select data for pretraining: are the documents on which compression is more reflective of models' abilities also better for training?

Here we bring PreSelect, a pretraining data selection approach that outperforms DCLM and Fineweb-Edu significantly on a scale up to 3B model trained on 100B tokens. We release our fastText-based data scorer as well as a 100B high-quality corpus for the community: https://t.co/vq8lTENzox

name: Paul Snively
full_text:
Here‚Äôs what I find frustrating:

Early in computer science as a discipline, it was understood that we needed to be able to reason about code. People like Dijkstra and Hoare described how to do it. One of the results was Floyd-Hoare Logic, which supports preconditions and post
note_tweet_text:
Here‚Äôs what I find frustrating:

Early in computer science as a discipline, it was understood that we needed to be able to reason about code. People like Dijkstra and Hoare described how to do it. One of the results was Floyd-Hoare Logic, which supports preconditions and post conditions to follow state changes. More recently, this has evolved into concurrent separation logics like https://t.co/RDq0TKAQcu that use the @CoqLang proof assistant to treat code in imperative languages building concurrent and distributed systems.

Coq itself is based on the other major approach to reasoning about code: by dealing with functions in the usual mathematical sense, logically constrained by a type system, with the logic supplied via the Curry-Howard correspondence. The advantage here is there are type systems that are not Coq‚Äôs, but powerful enough, that you can do this reasoning in your head, unlike Floyd-Hoare Logic or any concurrent separation logic.

Modern advocates of systems programming languages don‚Äôt exhibit any understanding of this. They‚Äôre actively hostile to typed pure FP, which we can set aside for the moment. But they also don‚Äôt know anything about reasoning formally about imperative or concurrent code in the languages they prefer.

All they‚Äôve got is ‚Äúget gud‚Äù and a royal pain in the ass attitude.

name: leloy!
full_text:
GRPO's Main Flaw

I've been testing different critic-free RL algos on multi-task environments, and one thing I've noticed is that GRPO seems to slightly underperform normalization-free variants. This tracks with the results in the LOOP paper.

Why? Most likely because GRPO's https://t.co/h5LodOnKKP
note_tweet_text:
GRPO's Main Flaw

I've been testing different critic-free RL algos on multi-task environments, and one thing I've noticed is that GRPO seems to slightly underperform normalization-free variants. This tracks with the results in the LOOP paper.

Why? Most likely because GRPO's normalization term, in a sense, penalizes large magnitude rewards. But in multi-task envs, these rewards are highly informative!

E.g.:
- If your agent gets a very low (negative) reward, then it must be getting things consistently wrong--and this must be punished severely. And
- If it gets a very high reward, then it must be getting things consistently right--and this must be encouraged a lot more.

---

Why haven't Deepseek and the rest of the open-source community catch this yet?

Because it doesn't matter for the way we currently train our reasoning LLMs anyway. We only have one source of rewards: the verifier at the end of the generation step.

But this is going to be a problem when you try to train an agent that need to complete multiple (verifiable) tasks per run (e.g. a browser agent). Be careful!

---

Yes, the goal of introducing a baseline is to reduce the variance of the gradient estimator to stabilize training. But this is the kind of variance we don't want to get rid of!

note_tweet_text:
Open source can plausibly beat the labs to AGI/ASI (for some definition of those terms), in the open, over the Internet. While there are still details to work out:

The flywheel is simply RL on many hard problems with verifiable outcomes. 

* Writing verifiers, searching for excellent rollouts, and refining them are all embarrassingly parallel. 
* There is more compute and software engineering talent outside of the labs than within them.
* @PrimeIntellect has already built and validated the data generation half of the flywheel. Their community of compute volunteers has produced and gifted 2M verified reasoning traces (2.5x what DeepSeek used for R1-Distilled) already.

This unlocks bushels of low hanging fruit. Nearly anyone can accelerate the open source flywheel by working out any of the following:

1. Reasoning data selection

To date: LIMO and simplescaling 1.1 both find that ~1k carefully selected reasoning traces from R1 are sufficient to distill reasoning capability into Qwen2.5-Instruct models.

Careful selection to date has meant filtering for hard problems by filtering out problems the instruct model can already solve, and sampling for diversity. But there is more to do:

A. Ensure the reasoning traces are in-distribution wrt the student by filtering samples for low loss. Just about every post-training paper of note published in the last year finds that in-distribution data is a big deal, including https://t.co/fRLME7sSAh and https://t.co/QGVu5Z2DFB, this is almost certainly going to work. But it needs to be validated, thresholds need to be determined, and if there is a curriculum learning play (like easier samples first), of course that would be good to know.

B. Filtering may be done at token scale: with human data, if one masks high-loss tokens to spare the model OOD tokens (cf. https://t.co/n9WoGcQjlZ), ~3/4 of the performance hit from human data goes away. This simple hack might well work for synthetic data, too. But the threshold will be important to find.

C. Prompts may be filtered for quality by looking at the variance in output reward, cf https://t.co/hdl9HXsvU8. It's unclear if this applies to traces with verified outcomes, but it probably at least applies to the rest of the post-training mix.

2. Distillation data refinement

A. Pruning

Reasoning traces are often long and sloppy, which is slow, expensive, and gratingly neurotic for the user at inference time. At least one paper (https://t.co/Anz5VOkAY8) shows efficiency and accuracy benefits to pruning reasoning traces.

The targets here ought to be length (shorter is faster/cheaper), loss on the target model to distill (lower loss samples limit harm to base model's distribution), and accuracy (the final answer must remain correct).

B. Establish pruning limits / pivot token data mixing laws.

One risk of pruning reasoning traces is the loss of pivot tokens. Student models presumably need to see some of these!

So, the optimal pruning vs. pivot token mix needs to be determined. Determining where it is most beneficial to leave them (perhaps more difficult prompts) will also be high value.

B. Re-writing reasoning traces for low loss

Distillation reasoning traces are by definition off-policy for the student. As such, they are liable to be out of distribution, which is Bad.

We can fix this by re-writing high loss portions of reasoning traces with a FIM model, then verifying semantic equivalence and lower loss on the target model.

It may even be possible to do this very cheaply with @jeremyphoward's ModernBert: use masked language modeling (like this: https://t.co/lIqRlRcNb7) to swap out tough tokens, and use distance of the embeddings for the original vs. modified sentences to estimate semantic equivalence.

C. Reasoning condensation

<thinking> tokens are neat, but sometimes they're overkill, and many (e.g., Dario) do not find them aesthetically pleasing.

If and when is it constructive to integrate them into the answer with a more normal CoT (like Claude)?

This seems particularly promising in cases where (say) an instruct version of a student model can answer the question correctly (so you would filter the question out if tuning from that instruct model), but you are starting fresh with the base model and want more verifiably correct instruct data in your SFT or midtraining mix.

D. Persona reasoning

Right now, R1 and its distillates think in slop. It will be much nicer for many purposes if reasoning models <think> in character. e.g., if my System Prompt says the model is Captain Ahab, "OK, the User wants me to pretend to be Captain Ahab, I should care about this whale," is lame, "I'll follow him around the Horn, and around the Norway maelstrom, and around perdition's flames before I give him up" is much more interesting -> likely to yield better results any time vibe is important (like creative writing) or the persona's particular reasoning patters are at issue.

3. Determine prerequisites for reasoning distillation:

Qwen2.5-Instruct models, which were mid-trained on lots of synthetic data, require less than 1,000 examples to learn long chain of thought (cf LIMO & simplescaling).

True base models require more than 1,000 examples, but no more than 800k examples (used in R1-Distilled). Dialing in filtered and SFT and midtraining datasets is going to be a big deal.

Now that the gains for post-training small to medium sized models are huge again, it's an ideal time to dial this in. Tulu 3 is the data mix to beat with clearer prompts (https://t.co/hdl9HXsvU8), unencumbered data, and in-distribution rollouts of exemplary quality (cf https://t.co/NtNn7b0Cra, https://t.co/tKeQDVCTtU, and https://t.co/quoBd7paeK for ideas)

4. Demystify the unreasonable effectiveness of DoRA.

.@winglian found that DoRA speeds up finetuning for reasoning by *a lot*. LoRA too --but not as much. Nobody knows why, but there's a quick and easy hypothesis to test: maybe FT is slower than LoRA is slower than DoRA because fewer weights are modified. 

If so, we would expect @DiLuo28's QuanTA (high-rank extremely sparse PeFT method) to be even better. This is extremely quick to test.

5. Build simple test-time compute levers.

The simplescaling folks (@Muennighoff et al) validated and wrote up something @_xjdr, @voooooogel, and others tweeted:

One can simply insert pivot tokens and forbid end-of-thinking tokens to force the model to reason longer.

The obvious next step for scaling TTC economically is branching on pivot tokens. i.e., if the model wants to 'wait', spawn a branch where that is replaced by an end-of-thinking token (or vice versa).

The other obvious thing is running multiple streams in parallel (which is reportedly what O1-Pro is doing).

From there, you need some means of selecting or aggregating one's responses. Majority voting, fuzzy majority voting via clustering embeddings, shortest-of-n, and selection via reward model have all been shown to work in some settings. They ought to be refined and compared.

note_tweet_text:
The @JeffDean & @NoamShazeer episode.

We talk about 25 years at Google, from PageRank to MapReduce to the Transformer to MoEs to AlphaChip ‚Äì and soon to ASI.

My favorite part was Jeff's vision for AGI as one giant MoE that is grown in bits and pieces over time like a forest, rather than trained all at once.

Specialization, distillation, inference time scaling all emerge organically rather than by design.

Noam bites every bullet: 100x world GDP soon; let‚Äôs get a million automated researchers running in the Google datacenter; living to see the year 3000.

Links below. Enjoy!

note_tweet_text:
btw I didn't do comprehensive research on this, I just try random stuff and compare over time, and I don't have too much confidence to recommend the right one for this yet. 

I happened to be using SuperWhisper recently and I'm happy with it functionality wise. I will say that by default I don't like when data from my computer goes anywhere outside of my computer via an opaque app. I prefer fully super duper fully offline apps (no pinging home, no updating unless I ask, no analytics no nothing), whenever possible, and I think speech to text should be a setting where this should be possible just fine.

I saw earlier that @simonw use MacWhisper so I have a todo to try that next. @jordibruin says in the app readme that "All transcription is done on your device, no data leaves your machine." and it's a one-time purchase.

note_tweet_text:
Today's nerd snipe:

> boiled eggs suck because yolk and white are best cooked at diff. temperatures

> talented chefs try to do this by cooking eggs sous-vide between 60¬∞C and 70¬∞C, but still not good enough unless they use complex techniques to separate white and yolk

> Nature paper figures out how to cook eggs evenly by duty-cycling the temperature of water between 30¬∞C and 100¬∞C every 2 mins, derived from a model of heat transfer between yolk and white

> @sdamico implements the paper using his stoves that can hold water steady at 30¬∞C and 100¬∞C

I wonder what other culinary unlocks are possible when your stovetop comes with a closed loop control system

note_tweet_text:
We've explored Netflix's predictive CPU isolation for containers and IIT Bombay's affinity-aware VM placement. But what about CPU pinning?

This 2020 study, the Art of CPU-Pinning: Evaluating and Improving the Performance of Virtualization and Containerization Platforms, examines how CPU-Quota vs. CPU-Set (pinning) impacts VMs & containers - adding another dimension to resource optimization.

Together, these three approaches tackle CPU performance from distinct but interconnected angles.

name: Daniel Han
full_text:
We managed to fit Llama 3.1 8B < 15GB with GRPO! Experience the R1 "aha moment" for free on Colab!

Phi-4 14B also works with @UnslothAI & vLLM is now integrated allowing 20x faster inference!

LoRA with GRPO also just work!

1. We removed double memory usage during vLLM serving
note_tweet_text:
We managed to fit Llama 3.1 8B < 15GB with GRPO! Experience the R1 "aha moment" for free on Colab!

Phi-4 14B also works with @UnslothAI & vLLM is now integrated allowing 20x faster inference!

LoRA with GRPO also just work!

1. We removed double memory usage during vLLM serving and finetuning - Unsloth now uses unified VRAM space for both - so you get 2x faster, 70% less VRAM finetuning and 20x faster inference all in one package! Use fast_generate for vLLM generation.

2. If you don't have W&B logging, we now show all metrics inside of Colab as well!

3. Thanks to @shxf0072 for the first Unsloth notebook to GRPO Qwen 1.5B and Llama 1/3B on GRPO on a free 15GB Colab - it helped a lot :) Now 14B param model fits!!  Also shout out to @willccbb for the original GRPO starter Colab! And @jiayi_pirate for TinyZero as well!

4. LoRA / QLoRA also originally did not work for people when doing GRPO in the starter script - Unsloth will correctly load LoRAs in vLLM!

5. Llama 3.3 70B GRPO QLoRA might fit in < 48GB VRAM - best to use 1x 80GB GPU!

Blog for more details: https://t.co/ic0OnLMKC5 

Phi-4 14B Colab notebook: https://t.co/Am2ZXtxLQd

Llama 3.1 8B Colab notebook: https://t.co/AeUCdkX8Je

Introducing Satori, a new framework for advancing LLM reasoning through deep thinking without a strong teacher model!

We achieve this through a two-phase https://t.co/CoUIlcJdqU
note_tweet_text:
LLM can perform autoregressive search!
LLM can perform autoregressive search!
LLM can perform autoregressive search!

Introducing Satori, a new framework for advancing LLM reasoning through deep thinking without a strong teacher model!

We achieve this through a two-phase post-training paradigm with Chain-of-Action-Thought (COAT):
‚úÖ a small-scale format tuning (FT) stage to internalize the COAT reasoning format 
‚úÖ a large-scale self-improvement stage leveraging reinforcement learning (RL)

The most intriguing result: despite being trained solely on a math dataset, the model's search capabilities generalize to other domains!

note_tweet_text:
A new paper shows that using L2 distance is better than using a dot product for classification loss.

* More expressive
* Higher stability
* Easier to learn

L2 distances have been a long-standing problem. They are frequently used in contrastive learning (Barlow Twins) but consistently underperformrf compared to the more popular InfoNCE.
However, @dbaek__ et al. propose a key change: weighting the distances to get probabilities.

Using this simple change, they get the more expressive L2 loss to converge well!
Instead of maximizing the angular distance between two vectors, we minimize the distance between two points in an N-dimensional hyperspace - love it.

https://t.co/1WhMWsToz1

Beyond Limited Data: Self-play LLM Theorem Provers with Iterative Conjecturing and Proving

Uses DS Prover as a base model to generate data in the resource scarce formal theorem proofs. The conjecturer is trained iteratively on previously generated conjectures that are barely https://t.co/aRdb6UxjFf
note_tweet_text:
Beyond Limited Data: Self-play LLM Theorem Provers with Iterative Conjecturing and Proving

Uses DS Prover as a base model to generate data in the resource scarce formal theorem proofs. The conjecturer is trained iteratively on previously generated conjectures that are barely provable by the current prover. The prover attempts to prove these with standard expert iteration. Using this method was able to prove 26.3% of the statements in the LeanWorkbook dataset.

Links below

note_tweet_text:
I'm sorry for sounding like Schmidhuber, but this "Budget Forcing" trick has already been done before in Structured Generation/Outputs literature

At the top of my head, I can recall:

1. @dottxtai's engineering blog where they've shown that manipulating the logits of frozen models to force them to reason before answering can make them outperform more expensive, parallel test-time scaling; and

2. My technical report for my winning submission for CVPR's Multimodal Foundation Models (MMFM) Challenge 2024 where I've shown that the same trick also works well on multimodal (document understanding) benchmarks. Links below.

I've already sent a citation request. I just want everyone to know about this very useful trick and previous work on it.

I just released Pragmatic Type-Level Design 1.1.0, featuring bug fixes and improvements.

It‚Äôs a book about type-level programming and design in Haskell, Rust, and Scala 3‚Äîyes, all three languages are covered in the book.

Buy Pragmatic Type-Level Design on LeanPub. A link with a 33% discount coupon is in the reply.

I'm especially proud that I discovered several approaches that are not only powerful and simple but also translate well across all three languages. One example is type-level interfaces, which have the potential to revolutionize type-level design.

Additionally, I have two pledges:

1‚É£If the book reaches 1,000 copies sold, I will write four more chapters and add two more languages to the Rosetta Stone section (in addition to Haskell, Rust, and Scala 3).

2‚É£If the book reaches 2,000 copies sold, I will write a comprehensive book on type-level programming in Rust. Buyers of Pragmatic Type-Level Design will receive a huge discount.

name: Chaithanya Kumar
full_text:
Hey folks 

I started getting deep into understanding how LLMs are built from the ground up ( I am always of the opinion that if you don't understand how something works from first principles, you will never be able to make the best out of it. ) 

Below are my resources 

1. https://t.co/PNBlT79mSw
note_tweet_text:
Hey folks 

I started getting deep into understanding how LLMs are built from the ground up ( I am always of the opinion that if you don't understand how something works from first principles, you will never be able to make the best out of it. ) 

Below are my resources 

1. Build a LLM from scratch book by @rasbt - this book is my starting point, and if you haven't already bought this book, I would suggest buying this. 

- I am documenting everything related to this book here ( Google docs) -> https://t.co/27mvWH6ROF

- I get too deep with respect to each concept. Not just at a higher level, but also like I get into the whys of things, the mathematics , and every single question that I get while learning about that particular piece of concept and its answer, I add these to the  doc , so it's very in-depth and you will have a much more deeper understanding along with the concepts from the book

- if I have to give you a simple example -  for  each stages of how to build a large language model, I always ask: - Why is this stage needed? - What is the objective of this particular stage? - What is the final model that comes out of this stage? - What is the mathematical formulation at each stage? - Finally, what are some examples?

- but by far the biggest unlock is adding more resources to this learning material , One is obviously the book but I I also recommend looking at the videos, particularly when you are learning the Introduction to Transformer Architecture,  The videos from @hkproj  is excellent. He's a legend. Hands down.

name: Mahesh Sathiamoorthy
full_text:
We are announcing Open Thoughts, our large-scale open-source effort to curate the best open reasoning datasets!

DeepSeek-R1 is amazing but we still don't have access to high-quality open reasoning datasets. These datasets are crucial if you want to build your reasoning models! https://t.co/2kU6z8zDdT
note_tweet_text:
We are announcing Open Thoughts, our large-scale open-source effort to curate the best open reasoning datasets!

DeepSeek-R1 is amazing but we still don't have access to high-quality open reasoning datasets. These datasets are crucial if you want to build your reasoning models!

Bespoke Labs released a 17k reasoning dataset last Wednesday, and the reception has been phenomenal (it's trending on HF).

So we are joining forces with the Datacomp community to launch Open Thoughts --- an open data, open model, and open code initiative for creating the best open reasoning datasets and the associated models.

Along with this, we release OpenThoughts-114k reasoning dataset and the associated OpenThinker-7B model.

Links to the code, model, and data are below in üßµ.

name: Daniel Han
full_text:
We quantized DeepSeek R1 to 1.58bit - 131GB so 80% smaller whilst being usable via dynamic quantization!

1. R1 has 3 dense + 58 MoE layers. MoE is quantized to 1.5bits. Attention & rest params in 4/6bit
2. 140 toks/s on 2xH100 80GB
3. Also found some tokenizer quirks!

Details: https://t.co/9YkOrXBdZR
note_tweet_text:

1. R1 has 3 dense + 58 MoE layers. MoE is quantized to 1.5bits. Attention & rest params in 4/6bit
2. 140 toks/s on 2xH100 80GB
3. Also found some tokenizer quirks!

Details:
1. DeepSeek R1's architecture uses 3 fully dense layers then 58 MoE layers. The MoE layers have shared experts as well, and Multi Latent Attention MLA replaces MHA. More detailed arch breakdown here: https://t.co/PdzLCoQClC

We leave the first 3 dense layers (0.5% of all weights), and all MLA weights (5% of weights) as 4 or 6bit, then quantize all MoE layers to 1.5bit (-1, 0, 1) with scaling.

2. Naively quantizing all layers breaks the model entirely, with infinite repetitions and gibberish. Also leaving the down_proj in higher precision is important as shown in our dynamic quants release - https://t.co/HkCMpDQPrG and the Super Weights paper: https://t.co/nr8uBBP4W9

3. DeepSeek by default adds a BOS. The <think> </think> tokens are individual tokens. Be careful of double BOS tokens during inference! The pad token should also be set correctly or you will get infinite generations if you want to further finetune R1 (or all distilled versions).

4. We used a qualitative pass@3 Flappy Bird Game benchmark - the goal is to ask the model to create a Flappy Bird Game in Python with 10 conditions like the background has to be a random color, or there is a best score etc.

5. Made 4 versions: from 131GB to 212GB:
1.58bit 131GB https://t.co/AK5HRRYQFY
1.73bit 158GB https://t.co/HfroXJ18rM
2.22bit 183GB https://t.co/cA8ZtKtzJW
2.51bit 212GB https://t.co/EvzKLkgjRD

> More details in blog here: https://t.co/2SGQsgbqQP
> All quants here: https://t.co/4tylmnVWA8

We replicated the DeepSeek-R1-Zero and DeepSeek-R1 training on 7B model with only 8K examples, the results are surprisingly strong. 

üöÄ Starting from Qwen2.5-Math-7B (base model), we perform RL on it directly. No SFT, no reward model, just 8K MATH examples for verification, the resultant model achieves (pass@1) 33.3% on AIME, 62.5% on AMC, and 77.2% on MATH, outperforming Qwen2.5-math-7B-instruct and being comparable to PRIME and rStar-MATH that use >50x more data and more complicated components. 
üöÄ Increased CoT length and self-reflection emerge

note_tweet_text:
How to find a job in Silicon Valley:

1) Ask yourself which companies have missions that you're most passionate about
2) Think about how you can help 
3) Do a few projects that show you can help (ie: coding, design, marketing concepts, educational blogposts, documentation, as long as it's relevant to the work / mission / company)
4) Reach out to the founders or senior employees directly (not via recruiting channels) and say "I'm passionate about your mission X for Y reasons. I think I can help by doing Z. Here are some projects that show I can do it."

If it doesn't work out, don't be discouraged. Ask for feedback. Reach out to more companies and founders that you're passionate about helping. Do more projects that show off your strengths. You'll make it.

You don't need an education or resume for any of this. Your projects, determination, and research are your education + resume.
