name: Peter Kraft
full_text:
SQLite is the most widely deployed database in the world, running on devices as ubiquitous as phones and TVs and as mission-critical as aircraft software. But how did it get there, and where is it going next?

I love this paper because it gives both a historical perspective on https://t.co/crAEaK3pl0
note_tweet_text:
SQLite is the most widely deployed database in the world, running on devices as ubiquitous as phones and TVs and as mission-critical as aircraft software. But how did it get there, and where is it going next?

I love this paper because it gives both a historical perspective on SQLite and an honest look at its advantages and shortcomings. SQLite originated 25 years ago as a small package of data management functions for Tcl, but rapidly evolved into a full-fledged transactional database. It became enormously popular for three big reasons:

- It‚Äôs embedded and self-contained. Uniquely among major databases, SQLite runs inside your application's process instead of on a separate server. It‚Äôs distributed as a single C file that compiles to less than 750 KiB. This lets SQLite run in resource-constrained environments where a conventional database would be unworkable.
- It‚Äôs cross-platform. A SQLite database is stored in a single file that can be freely copied across almost any machine, regardless of architecture. In embedded systems where custom architectures are everywhere, this is a huge advantage.
- It‚Äôs reliable. SQLite has a stunning 600 lines of test code for every line of SQLite code, covering all sorts of rare crashes and failure conditions. This is huge for mission-critical systems.

What‚Äôs interesting about SQLite is that while it was designed for transactional workloads, it‚Äôs increasingly used for analytical (OLAP) workloads just because it‚Äôs lightweight and easy to add to a data science library. Smart database researchers saw this trend and built an embedded analytics-focused database, DuckDB , which has also become very popular. A big chunk of the paper is devoted to a performance comparison of the two, and the differences are striking:

- On transactional workloads containing mostly small reads and writes, SQLite is 10-60x faster than DuckDB.
- On analytical workloads consisting of large scans, aggregations, and joins, DuckDB is 30-50x faster than SQLite.

This shows how important it is to pick the right system for your workload! Interestingly, the authors propose some optimizations for SQLite based on ideas from DuckDB, like using Bloom filters to speed up big joins. These make SQLite up to 4x faster on some analytical queries, though it‚Äôs still an order of magnitude behind DuckDB. Hopefully cross-pollination between databases continues to improve them all in the future!

name: jack morris
full_text:
spent the last month building my own framework to train a diffusion model from scratch.  it was hard

almost like i just learned to cast an ancient spell that requires lots of mysterious steps and ingredients.  for a long time i was trying, and nothing happened.  but when it
note_tweet_text:
spent the last month building my own framework to train a diffusion model from scratch.  it was hard

almost like i just learned to cast an ancient spell that requires lots of mysterious steps and ingredients.  for a long time i was trying, and nothing happened.  but when it worked it felt like magic

i've learned a lot so wanted to share a bit üßµ

- i'm doing *conditional* diffusion, trying to produce outputs x that depend on some inputs y.  my biggest blocker was that the architectural biases matter here ‚Äì  you can NOT put the conditioning directly into the input, or the model will just learn to map y to x instead of using y to denoise the noisy input x. (the loss will go down but sampling will not work)
- thus the diffusion world has a zoo of "conditional" architectures that can be a little challenging to adapt for your problem. but you have to use one or else things just won't work
- apparently, architecture still matters in vision (sad).   initialization, residuals, and extra normalization can make all the difference
- learning a small "probe" alongside your diffusion model is hugely valuable.  you can just cut the gradients to the probe so that it doesn't affect training.  this way you will know when you beat the baseline.  (i'm not sure if this is common practice but it was invaluable for me)
- you need to incorporate sampling into training every-so-often. otherwise you will never figure out why your model doesn't work
- the normalization is super important.  your input data needs to have ~mean 0 or std 1.  otherwise learning might not work,  or will be super slow
- in diffusion a lot of things can have the same shape but be different "types" in the sense that they're incompatible in some way.  easy to make these bugs and the code will still run.  and you often can find them by checking that the norms, stds, and means are approximately correct
- complex systems that you write from scratch will inevitably have tons of bugs.  you can start with trying to learn the identity function (in diffusion just set the noise to zeros).  if you can't do this something is broken.  in my case this helped me realize one of my losses had a sign flipped
- in my opinion the loss after 1000 steps or so is usually a reliable signal for debugging architectural changes
- diffusion people look down on DDPM as old and outdated but turns out it's still "good enough for government work" and worked fine for me eventually
- wouldn't recommend the diffusers library.  not sure it's really being developed anymore.  heard the openai impl is much better
- in general building systems from scratch is a slow and frustrating way to do research and i would recommend most people just start with a good codebase and tweaking it to fit your problem.  but if you build everything yourself you will learn a lot and feel a deep sense of satisfaction when it all starts working :)

name: Andrew Carr ü§∏
full_text:
Crazy new feature in Triton 

Basically, Warp specialization in Triton takes advantage of the GPU‚Äôs hardware-level concurrency by splitting your kernel into multiple asynchronous tasks (‚Äúwarp groups‚Äù). 

Each warp group runs in parallel‚Äîcommunicating efficiently via H100‚Äôs fast https://t.co/GDORoUuKpP
note_tweet_text:
Crazy new feature in Triton 

Basically, Warp specialization in Triton takes advantage of the GPU‚Äôs hardware-level concurrency by splitting your kernel into multiple asynchronous tasks (‚Äúwarp groups‚Äù). 

Each warp group runs in parallel‚Äîcommunicating efficiently via H100‚Äôs fast shared memory. 

You enable this magic by setting a couple of autotune flags, such as num_consumer_groups and num_buffers_warp_spec. Under the hood, Triton now **automatically** schedules these warp groups to run concurrently, squeezing more performance out of the GPU.

In the example above (a warp-specialized matrix multiplication), you see how they do standard Triton steps‚Äîloop over chunks of K, load A/B blocks, compute partial results, and then write them back. 

The key difference is the triton.Config specifying warp specialization parameters (like num_consumer_groups=2 and num_buffers_warp_spec=3). 

That‚Äôs it: Triton handles splitting and overlapping work so that each warp group can make better use of GPU resources.

name: Ishaan
full_text:
this paper (https://t.co/sWCjsytuX9) is what i was trying to find. 

the paper introduced a method to optimise the vector valued functions i.e. to optimize multiple objectives simultaneously (which often are interdependent). the jacobian matrix gives us info about how each https://t.co/RWtDqgvgiS
note_tweet_text:
this paper (https://t.co/RkrcA735KB) is what i was trying to find. 

the paper introduced a method to optimise the vector valued functions i.e. to optimize multiple objectives simultaneously (which often are interdependent). the jacobian matrix gives us info about how each component Fi(x) changes with respect to each variable xj‚Äã.

key aspects:

1. if you have two gradients that are conflicting (they have a negative inner product), simply summing them can result in an update vector that is conflicting with one of the two gradients. they avoid this phenomenon by using the information from the jacobian, and making sure that the update is always beneficial to all of the losses.

2. VRAM usage increases linearly with this method, at least with the current implementation.

name: Peter Kraft
full_text:
Can you ingest data safely and quickly in your data lake in <100 lines of Python?

Safely: Make sure customers see new data only after quality checks have passed, rolling back if they don't.
Quickly: Move files into Iceberg tables without processing or network bottlenecks.

This https://t.co/SNTSFSsgoN
note_tweet_text:
Can you ingest data safely and quickly in your data lake in <100 lines of Python?

Safely: Make sure customers see new data only after quality checks have passed, rolling back if they don't.
Quickly: Move files into Iceberg tables without processing or network bottlenecks.

This new demo from @jacopotagliabue shows how you can do this all in a small Python script by using DBOS with Bauplan.  It uses Bauplan to implement a write-audit-publish model, where data is first written to a staging branch of your lakehouse, then audited, then published to the main branch. DBOS durably orchestrates the pipeline, seamlessly recovering it in case of any kind of failure.

I love this demo because it highlights how lightweight both DBOS and Bauplan are: Bauplan lets you express complex infrastructural operations over your lakehouse as simple function calls, while a handful of DBOS decorators are all you need to make it fault-tolerant.

name: Wenhu Chen
full_text:
I spent the weekend reading some recent great math+reasoning papers:
1. AceMath (https://t.co/ftQZiyU3kj)
2. rStar-Math (https://t.co/N8bket1wpx)
3. PRIME (https://t.co/82oSXF3oa6)
Here are some of my naive thoughts! It could be wrong.

All of these papers are showing possible https://t.co/Mfir6h6J6m
note_tweet_text:
I spent the weekend reading some recent great math+reasoning papers:
1. AceMath (https://t.co/AB0y6X21u8)
2. rStar-Math (https://t.co/5aLdzcYgqV)
3. PRIME (https://t.co/p4kSH2Ig31)
Here are some of my naive thoughts! It could be wrong.

All of these papers are showing possible ways to reach o1. The secret source is pretty much the same thing: 
**high-quality/difficult prompt with verifiable answer**

1. AceMath takes a simple approach (rejection-fine-tuning -> RFT) to scale up all the SFT dataset to massive size based on the verifiable answer matching. No RM is necessary, but you can still use outcome RM to help boost the performance.
2. rStarMath uses self-evolving SFT approach to gradually boost the data quality and process preference model (PPM) performance. rStarMath is still an RFT, where the samples are coming from MCTS guided with PPM. Still, it requires strong supervision from the verifiable reward in the end. rStarMath also scales up inference compute by utilizing the PPM at each step.
3. PRIME takes a very different angle! PRIME actually uses PPO to train the model, but the major contribution is on how to assign the outcome's reward to each intermediate steps. It also relies heavily on using the verifiable answer to obtain the "correct" on-policy model outputs. 

The results are quite interesting. It seems that all these approaches are reaching similar results. Eurus-2 might seem weaker due to its smaller training set size. These results are all somewhat on par with o1-mini already/ Given some leakage that o1-mini is ~20B, it basically says that on there is no gap with o1 at least on math problems now. However, o1-mini might win significantly in other broader reasoning tasks, like physics, puzzles, etc. 

These results might reveal that reaching o1 is more of a data or infra problem than an algorithm problem. As we find great ways to scale up the (good and difficult prompt, verifiable answer) pairs from different domains, the actual algorithm might not influence too much. Some algorithms are more data efficient than the others, but many of them will take us to o1 or even o3.

note_tweet_text:
I built a tool that can help open the black box of AIs. 

It is called ‚ÄòProgrammed Conceptual Deconstruction‚Äô. It systematically breaks down any initial concept (Ci) into its constituent, related concepts through an iterative process until further decomposition is no longer possible.

It is convenient since it reveals the complete network of concepts that an LLM might associate with the initial concept, which helps seeing the understanding that any LLM might have of any topic.

The relationships between concepts are then visualized in a graph.

A demonstration follows below.

note_tweet_text:
Decentralized Diffusion Models

UC Berkeley and Luma AI introduce Decentralized Diffusion Models, a way to train diffusion models on decentralized compute with no communication between nodes.

Leveraging the associative property of the marginal flow (due to it being a linear system) to split  training into many independent sub-training jobs focused on producing  ‚Äúflow experts‚Äù that each model a subset of the data. These have no data dependencies to each other, so they can be trained wherever compute is  available. At inference time, they ensemble through a lightweight learned router.

The authors trained a 24B text-to-image diffusion model on eight independent nodes (8 GPUs each) for around a week.

Decentralized Diffusion Models outperform non-decentralized diffusion models FLOP-for-FLOP.

The "flow experts" can be distilled into a single monolithic model for easy inference.

‚Ä¢ Better: Outperforms on downstream tasks

‚Ä¢ Longer: 16x larger sequence length

On December 30th: 
Nomic AI brought us ModernBERT embed.

ModernBERT embed is a new embedding model built on ModernBERT-base, with all its advances:
‚Ä¢ Better: Outperforms nomic-embed-text-v1 and nomic-embed-text-v1.5 on MTEB
‚Ä¢ Faster: Immediate FA2 and unpacking support for  efficient inference
‚Ä¢ Longer: Embeds longer passages (up to 8,192 tokens)

Both ModernBERT and ModernBERT embed are Apache 2.0 licensed (fully commercially permissible).

note_tweet_text:
Four new research languages related to what @cmuratori mentioned (but that I realize will most likely be of very limited appeal to both the hosts and the audience of that stream).

1. Futhark:
- I like it because I want to solve mathy problems (i.e. scientific computing) in a mathy way (FP language).
- Also, because Futhark and Odin are both words pertaining to Norse stuff (LOL)
- And it's vector-oriented without looking as weird as say, Q.

2. Koka:
- A functional language that isn't "GC"-d (depends on your definition on what GC means)
- Fixes some of the issues I've faced with more conventional GC'd languages regarding latency issues.
- Effect handlers (typed continuations) are cool.

3/4. Hazel and Coalton
- A live functional environment. Hazel adds interactive live editing stuff to a Haskell/ML-style language, while Coalton adds a static ML-y type system to Common Lisp (and you get the CL goodies wrt interactive development).

name: Martin
full_text:
@vikhyatk I'm the author of several model merging libraries, so perhaps I can explain.

It's quite straightforward. When you finetune a LLM (or PEFT), you are taking a fixed base and tuning it against a dataset. Pretraining already fixed our parameters in a pretty solid matrix; so all
note_tweet_text:
I'm the author of several model merging libraries, so perhaps I can explain.

It's quite straightforward. When you finetune a LLM (or PEFT), you are taking a fixed base and tuning it against a dataset. Pretraining already fixed our parameters in a pretty solid matrix; so all changes must operate around this as the basis.

Training can't perturbate the base model outside of a certain range without the model collapsing, so viable changes will follow allowable patterns. This is why the resulting models are homomorphic. These trainings create kernels that are commonly known as 'task vectors'.

As long as these models remain homomorphic, and you only attempt to merge parts of the parameter space that are in the same alignment, two kernels can be interpolated to adjust the parameter space to have relative changes that assume the properties of both.

The alignment issue - this is where sign agreement comes in. Since merging generally compares the delta weights, it is possible that kernels may train out of phase. One kernel may have been trained in a positive phase alignment with the base model, and the other developed a negative phase alignment. Since they are out of phase with each other, their kernels would interfere.

I don't know if that's as clear as I would like it to be, but it's late.

note_tweet_text:
I really enjoyed watching this talk on the FreeBSD scheduler by Kirk McKusick. While the Linux scheduler algorithm is well known, very little is out there on the FreeBSD scheduler. This talk fills that gap. 

I didn't know but Kirk along with Bill Joy wrote the original BSD multilevel feedback queue scheduler (MLFQ) which is still available in FreeBSD. But, now FreeBSD has switched to a more sophisticated algorithm called the ULE scheduler which is well suited for multicore systems. 

Interestingly, in the Q&A, Kirk mentions that while the original 4.4 BSD scheduler (MLFQ) is around 100 lines of C, the new ULE scheduler is 2000 lines, and the Linux CFS is 20k lines of code. I think he cited this based on a Usenix paper which compared the two schedulers.

Link to the talk in reply.

name: Peter Kraft
full_text:
Want to learn how AWS built an innovative new key-value store that provides performance, consistency, and durability at massive scale?

Right now, the most popular key-value store out there is Redis, which is an amazing piece of software that combines incredible performance with https://t.co/pxvDwzU1s7
note_tweet_text:
Want to learn how AWS built an innovative new key-value store that provides performance, consistency, and durability at massive scale?

Right now, the most popular key-value store out there is Redis, which is an amazing piece of software that combines incredible performance with support for complex data structures. However, Redis isn‚Äôt durable or consistent at scale: it replicates data asynchronously, so distributed reads aren‚Äôt consistent and the loss of any node may lead to permanent data loss.

This paper describes how AWS built a new distributed key-value store, MemoryDB, on top of Redis to provide durability and consistency at scale. The big idea underlying MemoryDB is to decouple Redis‚Äôs execution engine from its durability layer. MemoryDB uses Redis as an in-memory execution and storage engine, but redirects its replication stream into an AWS transaction log service. This allows MemoryDB to be completely compatible with Redis while providing better guarantees.

Unfortunately, the paper is a bit light on details about how the transaction log service actually works. I‚Äôm interested in the next paper to learn more! But what they do describe is interesting‚Äìthe key idea is that since the execution engine and durability layer are decoupled, they can be scaled separately, so a database could run with a small number of (expensive) execution nodes but still be durable thanks to a large number of (cheap) transaction log nodes.

Another big focus of MemoryDB is providing strong consistency in case of failover. The key idea here is to implement a leader election mechanism that ensures that in case a primary fails, only a single new primary is elected and that primary is fully caught-up. The algorithm used is simple and clever: the transaction log service provides a conditional append API, where successfully appending to the log requires providing the unique ID of the preceding log entry. To become a new leader, a node has to append a new entry saying they‚Äôre the leader‚Äìwhich is only possible if they have the unique ID of the last log entry and are thus fully caught-up.

What‚Äôs the main takeaway?  The most interesting thing about MemoryDB in my opinion is how it builds on top of Redis. It composes the interface and high-performance single-node execution engine of Redis with a brand-new persistence and replication layer, thus enhancing Redis‚Äôs guarantees at scale.

name: Petr Baudis
full_text:
Quick primer for non-wizards about the post-MCTS LLM reasoning future (I'm kinda PRIME-pilled rn):

How will LLMs learn to reason? No math in this post, ~simple words only!

(I was rather intimidated by the original post as I wasn't keeping up with the LLM RL literature too much
note_tweet_text:
Quick primer for non-wizards about the post-MCTS LLM reasoning future (I'm kinda PRIME-pilled rn):

How will LLMs learn to reason? No math in this post, ~simple words only!

(I was rather intimidated by the original post as I wasn't keeping up with the LLM RL literature too much and it's very technical. But in fact it isn't that complicated!)

1. We are RL tuning an LLM to produce good CoTs (chains of thought). (Good == leading step by step to correct answers to complex queries.)

2. Basic approach is to use ORM (Outcome Reward Model) - try answering a query by rolling out a CoT, and check if it led to the right answer. This gives a positive/negative reinforcement to each token in the CoT (each token in the particular CoT gets the same reward).

The problem is that each rollout gives you only final outcome info, no sense if any particular CoT step actually helped move towards the result. Convergence is slow, so is ood generalization etc.

3. So let's give a per-CoT-step reinforcement using a PRM (Process Reward Model). Like teaching humans, tell them if they go in the right direction, don't just look at the final result. The very first idea explored was to just use per step human supervision during the CoT RL, but that's obviously unsustainable.

4. Enter MCTS-inspired approaches for automated PRM supervision. Given a few next possible CoT steps, which one is more helpful, can we tell automatically? Well, try rolling out the rest of the CoT ten times for each candidate, and see which one reaches the right answer most frequently!

The problem now is that you need to roll out the CoT ten times for each candidate - a Monte Carlo approach. This is not efficient as you are wasting a lot of time on stupid CoT step candidates and lost causes.

5. Finally, PRIME (Implicit Rewards PRM). The basic question is: Instead of MCTS-like evaluating each CoT step by N rollouts, could we just run a beam search of N rollouts of CoT from start to end?

Well, how do we know how to reward each token then?  Why, by finetuning an *extra* copy of your LLM internally to use as per-token reward model. This extra LLM copy is finetuned using the Outcome RM approach (so sparse rewards just encouraging tokens that lead to good final outcomes). This LLM is then used as a Process RM assigning a reward to each token based on its continuously learned estimate of how much that token is helpful.

"Continuously" learned? The reward model LLM and the main LLM epochs are interleaved - the estimates are learned in parallel with finetuning the main model, a sort of expectation-minimization dance.

Unlike just using ORM approach alone, this introduces an accretive effect - information on what works is shared across training batches through the reward LLM, and as it learns, it produces better guidance and the convergence of the main LLM speeds up.

PRIME of course also contains tons of important technical details. (Using PPO policy with alternative-normalized advantages rather than raw rewards. Keeping the initial finetuning LLM snapshot as a reference and considering only token logit changes to the reference, which makes the math work out. Formally proving it's better than MCTS. ...)

But this is the gist of the magic. And it results in reported 38x convergence speedup compared to MCTS.

Let's hope I didn't mess anything major up in this explanation, I'll add errata to replies if so (or original authors @lifan__yuan et al. perhaps might).

name: bubble boi
full_text:
Ludwig isn‚Äôt extreme enough. I tweeted this before and people thought I was joking but you are not a computer engineer if you haven‚Äôt built a computer from scratch. 

Write a basic ISA, design a simple 4 stage pipeline, memory mapped I/O, an assembler, compiler. Can you do memory
note_tweet_text:
Ludwig isn‚Äôt extreme enough. I tweeted this before and people thought I was joking but you are not a computer engineer if you haven‚Äôt built a computer from scratch. 

Write a basic ISA, design a simple 4 stage pipeline, memory mapped I/O, an assembler, compiler. Can you do memory allocation? Can you get a basic kernel running on it? This sounds hard. It really isn‚Äôt with some research. The point isn‚Äôt to make the best cpu or os but learn how they work fundamentally. 

You‚Äôre going to understand the real WHY behind some algorithms performing better than others when you need to come up with a cache eviction policy yourself. When you need to build memory pages yourself. 

If you want to learn about computers this is how you do it no shortcuts.

name: Romee Panchal
full_text:
All ML enthusiasts tapping into Deep Learning and NLP may have heard about the famous "Attention Is All You Need" paper. Implementing it from scratch is a great way to understand it. However, it has many prerequisites to understand it fully.

Below is the list of papers that you
note_tweet_text:
All ML enthusiasts tapping into Deep Learning and NLP may have heard about the famous "Attention Is All You Need" paper. Implementing it from scratch is a great way to understand it. However, it has many prerequisites to understand it fully.

Below is the list of papers that you should read and implement before proceeding to the "Attention Is All You Need" paper.

Start with Basic Neural Networks:
- Implement a simple feed-forward neural network from scratch
- Focus on backpropagation and gradient descent
- Paper: "Gradient-Based Learning Applied to Document Recognition" (LeCun et al., 1998) - implement a simpler version

Sequence Models Basics:
- Build a basic RNN from scratch
- Implement LSTM cells
- Paper: "Long Short-Term Memory" (Hochreiter & Schmidhuber, 1997) - start with a basic version

Word Embeddings:
- Implement Word2Vec
- Paper: "Efficient Estimation of Word Representations in Vector Space" (Mikolov et al., 2013)
- Understanding embeddings is crucial for transformers

Basic Attention Mechanisms:
-  Implement Bahdanau attention
- Paper: "Neural Machine Translation by Jointly Learning to Align and Translate" (Bahdanau et al., 2014)
- This is directly relevant to transformer attention

Sequence-to-Sequence Models:
- Build a basic seq2seq model with attention
- Paper: "Sequence to Sequence Learning with Neural Networks" (Sutskever et al., 2014)

Once you've implemented these, you'll have the foundation to understand:
- Attention mechanisms
- Positional encodings
- Multi-head attention
- Layer normalization
- Residual connections

These components all come together in the Transformer architecture.

note_tweet_text:
TangoFlux: Super Fast and Faithful Text to Audio Generation with Flow Matching and Clap-Ranked Preference Optimization

TangoFlux is a 515M parameter Text-to-Audio (TTA) model capable of generating 30 seconds of 44.1kHz audio in just 3.7 seconds on a single A40 GPU. It addresses alignment challenges in TTA models by using CLAP-Ranked Preference Optimization (CRPO), a framework for generating and optimizing preference data. Using CRPO, TangoFlux achieves sota results across objective and subjective benchmarks, with all code and models open-sourced.

note_tweet_text:
small rant on good vs. bad repos from a hiring perspective

these are bad:
- commit history is <5 commits or has an ‚ÄúAdd files via upload‚Äù message
- fork of a popular project with hardly any changes
- obvious template project from a stupid webdev or other online course
- idea that was obviously built for the purpose of filling out a resume rather than solving a real problem
- no instructions on how to run it locally, best case is if it‚Äôs actually deployed somewhere
- no small writeup about the intention and future plans
- has 5 collaborators and everyone claims all the work on their resumes
- massive faux pas for whatever language you‚Äôre using. like committing node_modules or venv
- if you‚Äôre applying to an e.g. python role and your most recent python repos demonstrate unfamiliarity with language features, standard libraries, etc. it‚Äôs usually not a good sign
- abstraction slop like using langchain when it‚Äôs absolutely unnecessary

my green flag is if it‚Äôs an idea inspired by a real problem the person has, has clear shell scripts/bash commands for how to run it, is committed to over a period of a few months which tells me it‚Äôs a project they‚Äôre actually interested in, shows knowledge of modern libraries (like uv for envs), and has clear modular commits that demonstrate problem solving and design skills

name: lada
full_text:
Nature just published a piece on why probability doesn't exist.
Lee Cronin said many times chemical reactions are not real.
Your genetics professor probably confessed to you before that there are no genes.
Biologists still disagree on whether cell types are even real.
And we https://t.co/7JEKDucaxY
note_tweet_text:
Nature just published a piece on why probability doesn't exist.
Lee Cronin said many times chemical reactions are not real.
Your genetics professor probably confessed to you before that there are no genes.
Biologists still disagree on whether cell types are even real.
And we already discussed how there is no such thing as aging.

This summarizes one of my favorite parts of doing science - the longer you stare at your cherished concept, the more it disintegrates and becomes non-existent. Seems to be a universal feeling - struggle to describe reality with words and numbers - experienced by many across fields.

name: Zhou Xian
full_text:
Everything you love about generative models ‚Äî now powered by real physics!

Announcing the Genesis project ‚Äî after a 24-month large-scale research collaboration involving over 20 research labs ‚Äî a generative physics engine able to generate 4D dynamical worlds powered by a physics https://t.co/4HRaTp5Gbs
note_tweet_text:
Everything you love about generative models ‚Äî now powered by real physics!

Announcing the Genesis project ‚Äî after a 24-month large-scale research collaboration involving over 20 research labs ‚Äî a generative physics engine able to generate 4D dynamical worlds powered by a physics simulation platform designed for general-purpose robotics and physical AI applications.

Genesis's physics engine is developed in pure Python, while being 10-80x faster than existing GPU-accelerated stacks like Isaac Gym and MJX. It delivers a simulation speed ~430,000 faster than in real-time, and takes only 26 seconds to train a robotic locomotion policy transferrable to the real world on a single RTX4090 (see tutorial: https://t.co/bEkIlCKqdf).

The Genesis physics engine and simulation platform is fully open source at https://t.co/DhBv7NdyqH. We'll gradually roll out access to our generative framework in the near future.

Genesis implements a unified simulation framework all from scratch, integrating a wide spectrum of state-of-the-art physics solvers, allowing simulation of the whole physical world in a virtual realm with the highest realism.

We aim to build a universal data engine that leverages an upper-level generative framework to autonomously create physical worlds, together with various modes of data, including environments, camera motions, robotic task proposals, reward functions, robot policies, character motions, fully interactive 3D scenes, open-world articulated assets, and more, aiming towards fully¬†automated data generation for robotics, physical AI and other applications.

Open Source Code: https://t.co/DhBv7NdyqH
Project webpage: https://t.co/SBNyhFB0yn

Documentation: https://t.co/3yuBoaealV

note_tweet_text:
Trying something new: I signed up for Params, a service that lets you browse curated ML project templates from open-source developers and book calls directly with the authors.

I'm starting with a flexible recommender systems template in Keras 3, that works with JAX, TF, and torch. If you're looking to add recommendations to your product, take a look at this codebase -- you should be able to make use of it easily.

It covers both cases where you only have binary interaction data (e.g. listens of a song) and cases where you have user ratings. Unlike a matrix factorization approach, it lets you incorporate arbitrary user features and item features into the predictions (thanks, Keras FeatureSpace API!)

note_tweet_text:
IBM, Princeton, CMU, and UIUC have just trained Bamba-9B which is a hybrid Mamba2 model, which reports 2.5x throughput and 2x latency improvements over Llama 3.1 8B using vLLM at 64k context length.

Here is the just published blog post:
https://t.co/3QRJnHVDNS

Transformer architecture works great but it's quite inefficient at inference time. Alternative architectures have been proposed to overcome Transformers limitations in particular for very long contexts.

Mamba is one of the recent inventions which uses State Space Models (SSMs), which speeds up inference thoughput and latency and excells at dealing with very long contexts.

If you're new to Mamba here is a good gentle explanation of how Mamba works and why it is a good replacement for Transformers
https://t.co/Xidnu1D3vq

name: Cameron R. Wolfe, Ph.D.
full_text:
My favorite paper from NeurIPS‚Äô24 shows us that frontier LLMs don‚Äôt pay very close attention to their context windows‚Ä¶

Needle In A Haystack. The needle in a haystack test is the most common way to test LLMs with long context windows. The test is conducted via the following https://t.co/ns7q49R38A
note_tweet_text:
My favorite paper from NeurIPS‚Äô24 shows us that frontier LLMs don‚Äôt pay very close attention to their context windows‚Ä¶

Needle In A Haystack. The needle in a haystack test is the most common way to test LLMs with long context windows. The test is conducted via the following steps:

1. Place a fact / statement within a corpus of text.
2. Ask the LLM to generate the fact given the corpus as input.
3. Repeat this test while increasing the size of the corpus and placing the fact at different locations.

From this test, we see if an LLM ‚Äúpays attention‚Äù to different regions of a long context window, but this test purely examines whether the LLM is able to recall information from its context.

Where does this fall short? Most tasks being solved by LLMs require more than information recall. The LLM may need to perform inference, manipulate knowledge, or reason in order to solve a task. With this in mind, we might wonder if we could generalize the needle in a haystack test to analyze more complex LLM capabilities under different context lengths.

BABILong generalizes the needle in a haystack test to perform long context reasoning. The LLM is tested based upon its ability to reason over facts that are distributed in very long text corpora. Reasoning tasks that are tested include fact chaining, induction, deduction, counting, list / set comprehension, and more. Such reasoning tasks are challenging, especially when necessary information is scattered in a large context window.

‚ÄúOur evaluations show that popular LLMs effectively utilize only 10-20% of the context and their performance declines sharply with increased reasoning complexity.‚Äù - BABILong paper

Can LLMs reason over long context? We see in the BABILong paper that most frontier LLMs struggle to solve long context reasoning problems. Even top LLMs like GPT-4 and Gemini-1.5 seem to consistently use only ~20% of their context window. In fact, most LLMS struggle to answer questions about facts in texts longer than 10,000 tokens!

What can we do about this? First, we should just be aware of this finding! Be wary of using super long contexts, as they might deteriorate the LLM‚Äôs ability to solve more complex problems that require reasoning. However, we see in the BABILong paper that these issues can be mitigated with a few different approaches:

- Using RAG is helpful. However, this approach only works up to a certain context length and has limitations (e.g., struggles to solve problems where the order of facts matters).
- Recurrent transformers can answer questions about facts from very long contexts.

full_text:
META JUST KILLED TOKENIZATION !!!

A few hours ago they released "Byte Latent Transformer". A tokenizer free architecture that dynamically encodes Bytes into Patches and achieves better inference efficiency and robustness!

(I was just talking about how we need dynamic https://t.co/aawPMIRjjG
note_tweet_text:
META JUST KILLED TOKENIZATION !!!

A few hours ago they released "Byte Latent Transformer". A tokenizer free architecture that dynamically encodes Bytes into Patches and achieves better inference efficiency and robustness!

(I was just talking about how we need dynamic tokenization that is learned during training ü•≤
It's like fucking christmas!)

I don't want to talk too much about the architecture.
But here's a nice visualization from their paper.

Let's look at benchmarks instead :)

"BLT models can match the performance of tokenization-based models like Llama 3 at  scales up to 8B and 4T bytes, and can trade minor losses in evaluation metrics for up to 50% reductions in  inference flops!"

This is basically a perplexity vs training flops chart - scaling laws with compute. BPB is a tokenizer independent version of perplexity.

BLT is on par or better than LLama 3 BPE!

Most importantly they scale this approach to train Llama-3 8B model on 1T tokens which beats the standard Llama-3 architecture with BPE tokenizer!

name: Chip Huyen
full_text:
During the process of writing AI Engineering, I went through so many papers, case studies, blog posts, repos, tools, etc. This repo contains ~100 resources that really helped me understand various aspects of building with foundation models.

https://t.co/5bjO19q655 

Here are the
note_tweet_text:
During the process of writing AI Engineering, I went through so many papers, case studies, blog posts, repos, tools, etc. This repo contains ~100 resources that really helped me understand various aspects of building with foundation models.

https://t.co/cmfZw5LgiX 

Here are the highlights:

1. Anthropic‚Äôs Prompt Engineering Interactive Tutorial

The Google Sheets-based interactive exercises make it easy to experiment with different prompts and see immediately what works and what doesn‚Äôt. I‚Äôm surprised other model providers don‚Äôt have similar interactive guides: https://t.co/D0IP1eCMOI

2. OpenAI‚Äôs best practices for finetuning

While this guide focuses on GPT-3, many techniques are applicable to full finetuning in general. It explains how finetuning works, how to prepare training data, how to pick training hyperparameters, and common finetuning mistakes: https://t.co/JENqR2V17I

3.  Llama 3 paper

The section on post-training data is a gold mine as it details different techniques they used to generate 2.7 million examples for supervised finetuning. It also covers a crucial but less talked about topic: data verification, how to evaluate the quality of synthetic data: https://t.co/n0ysigxy9q

4. Efficiently Scaling Transformer Inference (Pope et al., 2022)

An amazing paper co-authored by Jeff Dean about inference optimization for transformers models. It covers not only different optimization techniques and their tradeoffs, but also provides a guideline for what to do if you want to optimize for different aspects, e.g. lowest possible latency, highest possible throughput, or longest context length: https://t.co/hyKsp1QY2A

5. Chameleon: Plug-and-Play Compositional Reasoning with Large Language Models¬†(Lu et al., 2023)

My favorite study on LLM planners, how they use tools, and their failure modes. An interesting finding is that different LLMs have different tool preferences: https://t.co/cqRAlu9yOr

6. AI Incident Database

For those interested in seeing how AI can go wrong, this contains over 3000 reports of AI harms: https://t.co/zoHAb26SNX

7. I find case studies from teams that have successfully deployed AI applications extremely educational. Here are some of my favorite enterprise case studies. I'll add more case studies soon!

- LinkedIn: https://t.co/VWudyYlrB2

- Pinterest's Text-to-SQL:
https://t.co/BjwXGZeh5N

- Gmail‚Äôs Smart Compose (2019): https://t.co/AeCMGuthI6

- Grab: https://t.co/AYCs6ulNQt

note_tweet_text:
fun LLM research idea i had but am not working on:   Batch-compute recycling (BCR) 

Core intuition:  there is a lot of useful work unnecessarily recomputed between documents that share a lot of context

BCR would be a way to avoid redundant computation when processing a large number of documents, for example when asking a lot of questions about the same book,  embedding a lot of articles... 

a system using BCR would work in three steps: 
1. group documents into contexts ("Contextual batching"!) ‚Äì¬†producing a batch of related things x_1, x_2, ..., x_n 
2. use a large model to generate some "work" for each context ‚Äì¬†z ~ p(z | d_1, ..., d_n)
3. use a small model compute outputs for each document conditioned on both that output and z ‚Äì¬†p(y | d_1, z; Œ∏_s) 

if Œ∏_B >> Œ∏_S then this saves you about N compute where N is the number of related documents. probably in practice there would be a small performance decrease; have to tune N   

 someone should try it  :-)

I'm starting a series of tutorials to show you how to build agentic document workflows from scratch üß± - starting with an automated invoice agent üßæü§ñ

Agentic document workflows are a superset of RAG and encompasses a general set of actions that agents can take over their documents. A lot of workflows have the following common pattern: 
1. Start with an input task or document
2. Do extraction and ground it in relevant information from a knowledge base.
3. Interactively generate a report or take an action.

In this video, we build an end-to-end generative AI project from scratch. 

Problem Statement: You are an individual working in a headhunting company catering to startups and big tech. You want to automate the process of cold-emailing. Given the job post link, this video generates the email to be written to hiring manager.

name: Tanishq Mathew Abraham, Ph.D.
full_text:
Training Large Language Models to Reason in a Continuous Latent Space

Introduces a new paradigm for LLM reasoning called Chain of Continuous Thought (COCONUT)

Extremely simple change: instead of mapping between hidden states and language tokens using the LLM head and embedding https://t.co/YfXMh2fLoB
note_tweet_text:
Training Large Language Models to Reason in a Continuous Latent Space

Introduces a new paradigm for LLM reasoning called Chain of Continuous Thought (COCONUT)

Extremely simple change: instead of mapping between hidden states and language tokens using the LLM head and embedding layer, you directly feed the last hidden state (a continuous thought) as the input embedding for the next token.

The system can be optimized end-to-end by gradient descent, as continuous thoughts are fully differentiable.

note_tweet_text:
1. main options i can think of but seems none of them fit all the requirements  
    * datasette https://t.co/og15wPq3VL - closest to what they want but requires sqlite  
    * nocodb https://t.co/tfTJCaZxOK - good but needs proper db setup  
    * flat https://t.co/yo6kMuNqwg - requires gh actions  
    * postgrest https://t.co/REJKZYgBQq - needs postgres  

2. seems like there's a gap for a tool that can:  
    * take raw csv/json/etc  
    * infer schema  
    * create fast api endpoints  
    * zero config  
    * run locally or deploy easily  

---

but maybe something like this  

### 1. Crawl + Storage
```python
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import List, Optional
import polars as pl
@dataclass
class JobPosting:
    id: str
    title: str
    company: Optional[str]
    location: str
    salary_min: Optional[float]
    salary_max: Optional[float]
    skills: List[str]
    description: str
    source: str  # 'usajobs'|'bls'|'onet'
    posted_date: str

def fetch_jobs():
    # crawl endpoints
    usajobs = fetch_usajobs()
    bls = fetch_bls()
    onet = fetch_onet()
    
    # normalize to common schema
    jobs = [JobPosting(**job) for job in usajobs + bls + onet]
    
    # save to parquet for efficient querying
    df = pl.DataFrame([vars(j) for j in jobs])
    df.write_parquet("jobs.parquet")
2. Query API
from fastapi import FastAPI, Query

app = FastAPI()
df = https://t.co/3tePztMxY5_parquet("jobs.parquet")

@app.get("/jobs/search")
async def search(
    q: str = Query(None),
    skills: List[str] = Query(None),
    min_salary: float = Query(None),
    location: str = Query(None)
):
    result = df
    if q:
        result = result.filter(
            pl.col("title").str.contains(q, ignore_case=True) |
            pl.col("description").str.contains(q, ignore_case=True)
        )
    if skills:
        result = result.filter(pl.col("skills").arr.contains(skills))
    if min_salary:
        result = result.filter(pl.col("salary_min") >= min_salary)
    if location:
        result = result.filter(pl.col("location").str.contains(location))
        
    return https://t.co/InvWE59cAk_dicts()
```

Key Points:

* parquet for efficient storage/querying
* normalized schema across sources
* flexible search api
* typed everything for reliability

I wrote about a small probabilistic analysis about why does gossip protocol https://t.co/5c4JEa6fh4
note_tweet_text:
Gossip Protocols - a procedure or process of distributed systems where peer-to-peer communication that is based on the way gossip/epidemics/viral news spread. They are used to do reliable broadcasts.

I wrote about a small probabilistic analysis about why does gossip protocol ensure a very high rate of success.

I have two assumptions in my analysis/proof -
1. message size is small enough to be send in 1 request
2. we are choosing nodes randomly

I used Binomial distribution to formulate Gossip protocol and then used Poisson Approximation to do the analysis. 

https://t.co/7O4jcXrl5P

While I was teaching about Gossip protocol in empowered coder 8th cohort, I got a question how are we sure that gossip protocol will work, any minimum number of rounds or when to stop gossip.

name: Abhinav Upadhyay
full_text:
In this article I showed how to invoke a system call using the syscall instruction. This is common in x86-64 bit mode. But in 32 bit mode and earlier modes, the `int 0x80` instruction was used for doing this. Why is it not used anymore?

The `int` instruction causes a soft https://t.co/PeThXfqEV2
note_tweet_text:
In this article I showed how to invoke a system call using the syscall instruction. This is common in x86-64 bit mode. But in 32 bit mode and earlier modes, the `int 0x80` instruction was used for doing this. Why is it not used anymore?

The `int` instruction causes a soft interrupt to enter the kernel. It requires looking up the interrupt descriptor table and finding the interrupt handler for the given interrupt code. 

Reading of the interrupt descriptor table and looking up the address for the handler in it requires memory access. But syscalls are a very frequently done operation, to make it more efficient, x86-64 introduced a dedicated instruction which could avoid memory reads.

To do this the syscall instruction enforces a single point of entry for all syscalls, as a result no memory lookup is required . The syscall entry code figures out the syscall based on the value in the rax register and then calls its implementation. The following is the syscall entry code in Linux for x86-64:

note_tweet_text:
Reading this paper: 'Why Events Are A Bad Idea (for high-concurrency servers)'

This paper came out in 2003. Its core argument was that thread implementations in existing programming languages were shit and we could do better. They liked threads because of the linear programming model and their lower cognitive load. They implemented user-level cooperative threading which translates any blocking I/O to asynchronous requests internally (similar to Go?) and showed that threads can perform as well as events.

It's a companion to the 'Why Threads Are A Bad Idea (for most purposes)' (1995) paper. You need to understand both conflicting views for max üçø

full_text:
Finally finished Adam-mini!  A "mini" version of Adam that painlessly frees 50% of memory over Adam. Some highlighted features:

1. Adam-mini saves 50% memory over Adam for all modern neural nets. This is done by removing 99.9% Adam's v (but the last 0.1% of v is essential and https://t.co/kl6xPDm7Zo
note_tweet_text:
Finally finished Adam-mini!  A "mini" version of Adam that painlessly frees 50% of memory over Adam. Some highlighted features:

1. Adam-mini saves 50% memory over Adam for all modern neural nets. This is done by removing 99.9% Adam's v (but the last 0.1% of v is essential and necessary).

2. Adam-mini's loss curve closely resembles those of Adam. You can almost see no difference!

3. Adam-mini uses the same hyperparams as Adam (lr, beta1, beta2, eps, etc). No tuning is needed!

4. With the free memory you can enlarge batch size and achieve higher throughput (see paper). 

5. Principled design: The design of Adam-mini follows a very simple and general principle related to the Hessian structure of neural nets. Such design stems from classical optimization theory (see paper).

Paper: https://t.co/1OtYgL6Flp

Code: https://t.co/Ou8JcYiV9F

Very interesting.

DeMo syncs only the fast components of the signal, while the other slower components are accumulated in the momentum.

Two things that comes to my mind is this intuition to keeping the slow gradients (grokfast: https://t.co/65EnkARGsm), and reducing communication via taking a low-rank of the gradients (galore: https://t.co/bnNVDOh1QP).

name: Arjester
full_text:
How to Kickstart your ML Journey

The Philosophy for Learning:
Many of you want to start learning ML whether it‚Äôs for a side project, getting into the field, or just gaining the skills to up your market value. Regardless of your motivation I‚Äôm guessing this is how you came to
note_tweet_text:
How to Kickstart your ML Journey

The Philosophy for Learning:
Many of you want to start learning ML whether it‚Äôs for a side project, getting into the field, or just gaining the skills to up your market value. Regardless of your motivation I‚Äôm guessing this is how you came to this article:

1- Got interested in ML somehow
2- Started looking into how to start
3- Saved a bunch of resources and guides
4- Haven‚Äôt done any of them

Often the hardest parts of learning are the end when you start to reach the really heavy shit, and the complete beginning where you are lost and overwhelmed which leads to procrastination. This is normal but sucks ass so I‚Äôm going to tell you how to get past it and actually make progress.

The best model for this is the 10,000 hours mantra Karpathy shills constantly. In short this means that if you put in 10,000 hours into anything you will become good at it, maybe not the best but greatly competent. With this model by putting in 10,000 hours it doesn‚Äôt matter where you start as long as it‚Äôs the elementary levels because throughout those 10,000 hours you will discover what you need to know that you don‚Äôt already, filling in knowledge gaps until you get to the cutting edge.

Now here‚Äôs how I‚Äôm going to motivate you with this, if you put in 1 hour a day it will take you approximately 30 years for this level of mastery. That‚Äôs a long fucking time, but consider this: moving to 3 hours a day brings you down to 10 years, and moving to 10 hours a day brings you to 3. This means that with every extra hour put in every day you are saving years until mastery which gives you more time to make an impact with your skills.

So in relation to ML you need to be putting in the effort and JUST START SOMETHING, literally anything. Put the hours into a resource, practice what you‚Äôve learned with projects, then find knowledge gaps and fill them. Iterate through this process until mastery, but although motivating this still leaves room for confusion which can be used as another procrastination method. So I will take away this friction to your learning now with some places to start.

How to Actually Start:
Remember this article is written by me in a place to where I too am just starting my ML and CS journey, the main purpose is to KICKSTART you into your own studies. With that in mind here are someplaces to start with resources linked below. Most of this shit will be plagiarized from moots in tpot who have helped me with my own shit, so without further ado here is some starting places.

Do you know the math for ML (Calculus, Linear Algebra, Stats and Prob)?
Nuh uh:
- ‚ÄúMathematics for Machine Learning‚Äù by Marc Peter Deisenroth, A. Aldo Faisal, Cheng Soon Ong
- Math Academy Grind (Do ML Roadmap there)
„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Éë„Éë:
- ‚ÄúThe Hundred Pages Machine Learning Book‚Äù by Andriy Burkov
- Andrew Ng‚Äôs coursera or youtube lectures

Do you just want to start doing project based shit?
„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Éë„Éë:
- Start learning Pytorch via youtube or ZTM
- Start with random project idea and use LLM/Search Engine to learn things you need to know to build it

Are you reading this not even knowing how to code with Python?
„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Éë„Éë:
- ‚ÄúAutomate the Boring Stuff with Python‚Äù by Al Sweigart
- Leetcode
 
There, now pick something and do it.
Learn -> Apply -> See Knowledge Gaps and Iterate
Thanks for reading and good luck on accelerating anon.

Announcing new open-source Python package: aisuite!  

This makes it easy for developers to use large language models from multiple providers. When building applications I found it a hassle to integrate with multiple providers. Aisuite lets you pick a "provider:model" just by changing one string, like openai:gpt-4o, anthropic:claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022, ollama:llama3.1:8b, etc. 

pip install aisuite

Open-source code with instructions: https://t.co/gwz9oKTCFx

i learnt the most when i stopped thinking i needed a youtube video to learn everything. after a point, it's just not convenient. you have to read. there's no other way.

the first thing i read was an article on building a text editor in C, and i'm so glad i did. in just a week, i https://t.co/EObDCUC8RI
note_tweet_text:
i learnt the most when i stopped thinking i needed a youtube video to learn everything. after a point, it's just not convenient. you have to read. there's no other way.

the first thing i read was an article on building a text editor in C, and i'm so glad i did. in just a week, i learnt about memory management, system calls, pointers (finally), unix terminals, escape sequences, and so much more. it blew my mind when i figured out what happens when you press special keys like home, end, or combinations like ctrl + something. i learnt more in that week than i did in the entire year before.

it was the best thing i ever did. and no, there's no fun (or progress) in just reading it once and copying the source code. tweak it. make it your own. the code was just 1k lines of C in a single file, but i modularized it and learnt about #include guards, translation units (basically c source files), and Makefiles.

the best part? i didn't have to use any third party library.

note_tweet_text:
one of the BEST ways to learn is to repeatedly build stuff that pushes the boundaries of your skillset. progressive overload style

SO im starting a "learn by building" group, centered around building ML/math/programming/etc projects that challenge you, causing you to skill up in order to complete them

by doing this you'll grow your skills, and by doing it in a community you'll inspire/help others and get inspired by others. join if youre going to build a project, or if you already are building one

https://t.co/byDyJfDGB2

this has been how I've learned almost all of my programming/engineering skills, and it's EXTREMELY effective. "I want to learn RL" -> I build a small RL project -> I build a bigger one -> I am forced to learn tons of skills to complete each project and become decent at RL

How to do this:
1 pick a skill you want to learn/improve
2 build something that pushes you to grow that skillset
3 post updates when you make significant progress

in progress posts, it helps people/is fun when you put interactive demos, images/videos of your awesome progress, or write about what helped you (resources tips etc)

da rules: 
every post MUST include progress bc this is centered around actually doing work, not just sharing resources

name: leloy!
full_text:
Here's another reason why we would want to do steepest descent under the Spectral Norm:

To have a larger spread of attention entropy and thus allowing the model to represent more certainty/uncertainty states during training!

---

First, why do we have to bother with the https://t.co/gxG5Uhi382
note_tweet_text:
Here's another reason why we would want to do steepest descent under the Spectral Norm:

To have a larger spread of attention entropy and thus allowing the model to represent more certainty/uncertainty states during training!

---

First, why do we have to bother with the attention entropy in the first place? Because apparently, softmax disperses the attention coefficients through the context and through the layers! This makes them more uniform (especially at higher temperatures), thus increasing entropy.

This means that the larger your model is and the longer your context is, the bigger the chances of a "wrong answer" getting selected even if the "right answer" token has the highest probability of getting selected!

This paper [softmax is not enough](https://t.co/m0itIDe3it) explains this phenomenon much better & they propose some kind of 'adaptive temperature' on the softmax ops.

There's also an entropy-aware sampler, [Entropix](https://t.co/agnPBq6D8Z), that aims to counteract this effect at inference time.

---

But why don't we counteract this effect at train time?

Tbh, I don't know how to do this explicitly yet. But, we should at least pick an optimizer that doesn't collapse attention entropy to some small range of values

(1/n) üßµ

full_text:
Today I learned that my ideas and my books have massively influenced  @juspay, one of the biggest Haskell and Rust companies in the world. 

Vimal Kumar, the CEO of Juspay, who was also one of the first supporters of my Functional Design and Architecture book, told me that https://t.co/6AKbyTawgl
note_tweet_text:
Today I learned that my ideas and my books have massively influenced  @juspay, one of the biggest Haskell and Rust companies in the world. 

Vimal Kumar, the CEO of Juspay, who was also one of the first supporters of my Functional Design and Architecture book, told me that recently they developed several new successful services.

The EulerHS Haskell framework I and that I and my team designed for Juspay, is now used for one of the parts of NammaYatri, "an Open Source equivalent of Uber". The service is currently trending, as Vimal mentioned.

He also said that they developed an open source implementation of EulerHS in Rust. They then created a new product, HyperSwitch, an open-source payment platform, which has already gained 12K stars on GitHub already.

The EulerHS framework is the older brother of my educational Hydra framework developed specifically for the Functional Design and Architecture book. They are very similar in their ideas and architecture and share a certain "fingerprint" of my brain in them.

This is absolutely wonderful. I influenced a huge company (1300 people) at a time when it was small (around 30 people). My ideas and my book played a significant role in its success (not to forget other folks who actually wrote a lot of business logic which is 99% of the code). Vimal Kumar, a great Indian businessman, has been one of the first supporters of the book. He donated a lot, hired me and allowed me to implement my approaches. And he said he regularly reads and re-reads the relevant parts of my books.

name: rayüñ§üá∞üá∑
full_text:
ok friends, here's my end to end explanation of MLOps and infra for an LLM service based on my experience:

caveat; MLOps for LLMs is WAY different from classic supervised learning. forget data drift -- you're fighting hallucination, latency, and rlly high costs

most beginners
note_tweet_text:
ok friends, here's my end to end explanation of MLOps and infra for an LLM service based on my experience:

caveat; MLOps for LLMs is WAY different from classic supervised learning. forget data drift -- you're fighting hallucination, latency, and rlly high costs

most beginners do need an example with a supervised learning ML service (which trust me you will mostly work on in big companies) so lmk if you want a separate post on that

anyways, here's full end to end process:

1) infra (using AWS cuz that's my shit but same concepts for any cloud service):

use CloudFormation or CDK but I always use CDK
- ex: https://t.co/LbBEvPjF5Z
- your stacks:
- compute (ECS or whatever u choose)
- networking (LBs, VPCs, etc.)
- monitoring (CloudWatch alarms, metrics, etc.)
- data (s3, permissions, auto scaling, etc.)
- git hooks for auto CDK diff checks or just use AWS cloudformation stack drift feature

2) model hosting (use SageMaker):
- single or multi-model endpoints (choose based on model size & memory needs)
- custom containers for deployment
- some type of cron job, stpe function, or rly any offline job to put your model .pt files in s3
- model reloading via S3 triggers or SNS or lambda or event bridge rules doesn't matter just something automatic
- separate endpoints for:
- prod traffic
- shadow testing
- canaries for testing integration

3) request pipeline (ur service):
- API Gateway for handling requests and auth
- Lambda or ECS depending on your problem
- rate limiters if u have enough traffic
- ElastiCache because reading from prod db = skill issue

4) monitoring (in real apps w real customers u need this):
- CloudWatch metrics tracking:
- p50/p90/p99 latency, server/client side error rates, etc.
- token usage ($$$ tracker basically)
- auto-rollbacks on:
- error rate > 1%
- p99 latency > 2s
- significant deviation in key performance metrics (very model-specific) tbh humans still should look at this part in LLM services

5) data pipeline:
- Step Functions for any offline preprocessing
- S3 for your processed data and model artifacts
- DB and cache of ur choice for:
- prompts
- response cache
- user feedback
- config

6) CI/CD:
CodePipeline with:
- auto tests
- canary analysis
- separate pipelines for:
- infra
- app code
- model updates
- prompts

To sum up:

this is what ML ops and infra looks like for people who are new to the topic -- it's just a lot of considering different things for your specific problem. very backend heavy. slight knowledge needed to understand intuition of your ML models which drive infra decisions

the MOST important thing isn't the tech stack -- it's knowing when to use what. you don't need kubernetes if you're serving 10 requests/day just like you don't need multi-region deployment for your side project nor auto rollbacks nor caching

drop a follow if this helped. I can do deep dives on any part where u want

ps: again, if ur new to ML ops stick with a supervised learning problem using something simple like a model that uses random forest or something that way you learn abuot data drift and actually versioning data in the pipeline

note_tweet_text:
When I finished my first MLX implementation of the physics-informed Transformer for Heat Diffusion, about a 8 months ago, it would take ~ 8.5 hrs to train the model on a single M2U node using a particular dataset. 

Today, after replacing numpy functionality with new MLX features as they became available , implementing @compile, Quantization-Aware Training, RoPE, Lamb Opt, mpi-based distributed MLX, I can train the model on the same dataset on 2 MU2 nodes in ~2.5 hrs. üöÄüöÄ

Have learned so much in the process. Hope to pass insights to my students and others, and will be posting the updated code on the GitHub repo for ‚ÄúBeyond Language‚Äù. Just need to clean it up a little and will post link when ready in a couple of weeks. @awnihannun @angeloskath

name: Dmitrii Kovanikov
full_text:
Tomorrow, you'll go to your job.

You'll attend another pointless stand-up.
You'll do another unfulfilling task.
Your wife will complain you don't earn enough.
You'll be too tired even to play video games.

If you want to change all of that, here's my advice on how to find a
note_tweet_text:
Tomorrow, you'll go to your job.

You'll attend another pointless stand-up.
You'll do another unfulfilling task.
Your wife will complain you don't earn enough.
You'll be too tired even to play video games.

If you want to change all of that, here's my advice on how to find a Functional Programming job:

1. Learn an FP language. No, FP in TypeScript or Python doesn't count. You need to learn the essence of FP. I suggest OCaml, Haskell, Clojure or Elixir.

2. Join a FP community. FP jobs are so rare, they go away immediately as they appear. Usually, they don't even go to job boards, and are often posted in community forums, so you'd better monitor them! Besides, networking is essential.

3. Participate in OSS. Again, in FP, OSS communities are more active. Great for networking too.

4. Monitor FP job sites to see if there's anything relevant: https://t.co/QxsnV2oGc5

5. Apply for jobs. Even if you think you don't have relevant experience. People in FP communities perfectly understand that it's nigh impossible to get industrial experience with an FP language, so they're usually more flexible with requirements.

6. Prepare for a marathon. It's not a one-week process; it may take months or years. Getting your first FP job is hard, but getting your second FP job is no different from any other language.

note_tweet_text:
Popular interview question: how to diagnose a mysterious process that‚Äôs taking too much CPU, memory, IO, etc? 
 
The diagram below illustrates helpful tools in a Linux system. 
 
üîπ‚Äòvmstat‚Äô - reports information about processes, memory, paging, block IO, traps, and CPU activity. 
üîπ‚Äòiostat‚Äô - reports CPU and input/output statistics of the system. 
üîπ‚Äònetstat‚Äô - displays statistical data related to IP, TCP, UDP, and ICMP protocols. 
üîπ‚Äòlsof‚Äô - lists open files of the current system. 
üîπ‚Äòpidstat‚Äô - monitors the utilization of system resources by all or specified processes, including CPU, memory, device IO, task switching, threads, etc. 
 
Credit: Diagram by Brendan Gregg

Structured input is just as effective as structured outputs when building with LLMs.

Check out this new paper if you are working on RAG systems specifically.

It presents a novel approach that proposes using HTML instead of plain text as https://t.co/8UvdsCRnFt
note_tweet_text:
HtmlRAG: HTML is Better than Plain Text

Structured input is just as effective as structured outputs when building with LLMs.

Check out this new paper if you are working on RAG systems specifically.

It presents a novel approach that proposes using HTML instead of plain text as the format for building RAG systems.

The key finding is that preserving HTML structure provides richer semantic and structural information compared to plain text conversion, which typically loses important formatting like headings, tables, and semantic tags.

To address the challenge of HTML documents being too long for LLM context windows, the authors develop a two-step pruning method: first cleaning unnecessary HTML elements (reducing length by 94%), then using a block-tree-based pruning approach that combines embedding-based and generative pruning to further reduce the content while maintaining important information.

Experiments across six different QA datasets demonstrate that HtmlRAG outperforms existing plain-text-based methods, validating the advantages of preserving HTML structure in RAG systems.

note_tweet_text:
The particular point I was making was about his ; "locality" markers in the context, such that pulling a variable to the left of the ; is an irrevocable commitment, which you may not want in some situations: e.g. let generalization.

Mind you, if you are sufficiently disciplined, you _can_ still do this in the GHC-style mutable variable approach, e.g. Kuan and McQueen track the equivalent of the ; count before you hit a variable in the context as its "Œª-rank".

The main thing I like that his dissertation does is tear apart the big black box of Hindley-Milner style inference, and cleaves apart some things that are usually treated monolithically (e.g. unification) in such a fashion that it becomes much more obvious how to add functionality that doesn't fit the usual limitations of H-M.

GHC achieved much the same by formalizing  OutsideIn(X).

The zipper part is kind of cute, but I think falls out of just compiling and producing a witness in whatever core language you are using.

name: LlamaIndex ü¶ô
full_text:
We‚Äôre excited to feature a new RAG technique - dynamic section retrieval üí´ - which ensures that you can retrieve entire contiguous sections instead of naive fragmented chunks from a document.

This is a top pain point we‚Äôve heard from our community on multi-document RAG https://t.co/W7LogvSyHA
note_tweet_text:
We‚Äôre excited to feature a new RAG technique - dynamic section retrieval üí´ - which ensures that you can retrieve entire contiguous sections instead of naive fragmented chunks from a document.

This is a top pain point we‚Äôve heard from our community on multi-document RAG challenges - naive RAG returns fragmented context without awareness of the surrounding document. Our approach allows you to start off with a ‚Äúsimple‚Äù chunking technique (e.g. per page), but do a post-processing workflow to attach section/sub-section metadata.

You can then do GraphRAG-like retrieval (two-pass retrieval): retrieve chunks, look up the attached section metadata, and then do a second call to return all chunks that match the section ID.

https://t.co/mzZXN4QYtx

Save the web.

Obsidian Web Clipper is our new extension that helps you highlight and capture the web in your favorite¬†browser.

Anything you save is stored as durable Markdown files that you can read offline, and preserve for the long term.

Web Clipper makes it easy to shape Obsidian into a recipe book, a personal movie database, a travel planner, or read-it-later inbox. It turns your favorite browser into a sharper tool.

Web Clipper is available for all major browsers on desktop and mobile, including Firefox, Safari, Chrome, Brave, Arc, Orion, and many more. It‚Äôs also open source under the MIT license.

exo blew up way sooner than I expected. When we open sourced it 119 days ago, I was planning for a slow start where we would work in the open, pick up a few core contributors along the way, and maybe after a year if we did a great job we would https://t.co/sfKOhIct0L
note_tweet_text:
exo is trending on GitHub again.

exo blew up way sooner than I expected. When we open sourced it 119 days ago, I was planning for a slow start where we would work in the open, pick up a few core contributors along the way, and maybe after a year if we did a great job we would have built something people love.

Instead, exo in its most primitive form captured thousands of developer's imaginations. They worked through bugs, contributed hundreds of commits, and we are way further ahead than I ever thought we'd be at this stage. I definitely underestimated the power of the open source community.

On top of that, there is a lot happening behind the scenes that I am beyond excited about. More on that soonTM.

If you are a capable individual excited by our mission and want to join our journey, we are hiring (see @exolabs).

Tess-R1 has the https://t.co/tqXkYtAtfK
note_tweet_text:
Today, I'm open sourcing the first model of the Tess-R1 series, Tess-R1-Limerick, based on Llama-3.1-70B.

Tess-R1 is designed with test-time compute in mind, and has the capability to produce a Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning before producing the final output.

Tess-R1 has the following capabilities:
1. CoT step-by-step thinking: Uses <thinking> </thinking> tags to indicate when the model is performing CoT.
2. <contemplation> </contemplation> tags are used when the model contemplate on its answers.
3. <alternatively> </alternatively> tags are used for alternate suggestions.
4. Finally, <output> </output> tags are used for the final output.

Access the model weights here: https://t.co/FQyKTWho9J

name: Elliot Arledge
full_text:
for those of you scouting for "AI projects" to work on in your free time, i figure i would share the list of projects im currently doing to get a sense of how i carefully pick out problems:

1. write a training run in CUDA for some neural net you find cool. i started off w/ a
note_tweet_text:
for those of you scouting for "AI projects" to work on in your free time, i figure i would share the list of projects im currently doing to get a sense of how i carefully pick out problems:

1. write a training run in CUDA for some neural net you find cool. i started off w/ a single hidden layer MLP and gave myself a template to build from there

2. tinker w/ minecraft AI agents. multiple parts to this which make it even more fun (yes, you will get rapid dopamine hits while building). first you have to get an environment working (pixel output + action input) which i highly recommend "minerl" for . then you have to collect a bunch of training data in the form of minecraft video clips with actions each frame of the video (either your own or a massive corpus online -> also comes with minerl). next, you train the first neural net to take in a sequence of images from a video and you try to predict all the actions done in a given frame (say 7 frames total where the one you are trying to predict actions for is the middle frame -> temporal dimension helps performance). after this smaller neural net knows how to generate action labels from any given minecraft video, you can scrape thousands of hours of gameplay from youtube and run your small "data generator" neural net in inference mode to get yourself a nice dataset. then you test and tinker with different neural net architectures to actually attempt to reach goals in minecraft. you could use only neural nets, or neural nets w/ a mix of fixed algos (state machines, conditionals). 

3. mechanistic interpretability on computer vision networks and small language models. i personally started off by training an MLP from scratch on the mnist dataset up to around 98% accuracy then used matplotlib to print out the weights and activations in certain ways. helps you understand how neural nets form patterns internally in order to predict labels for the data you train it on. then you could use libraries like transformer_lens to visualize the attention heads at each layer for any given prompt in llms like gpt2-medium / small. if you're gonna go beyond that just looking at the raw patterns with your own eyes, consider playing with sparse autoencoders (if you find the resources hard to navigate just shoot me a dm). they essentially take a bunch of dense values in activations and project it to a sparse tensor format so you can map sparse signals to features (keywords you'll find here are: superposition/polysemanticity & dictionary learning).

4. fire up an instance with at least 2 3090s or 4090s and try to train a neural net of your choice across them with pytorch DDP (data distributed parallel) to give yourself an intro to distributed training/inference.

5. or if these sound crazy and you want a surprise, try implementing a neural net paper from arxiv in pytorch (a paper on "differential attention" came out recently which i'd like to mess around with. you could too)

6. if you think some resources need to be explained or documented better and you see the value in doing so, consider making a tutorial and posting it on X or youtube (i posted a few courses on the freecodecamp youtube channel and people liked them a lot). 

again, please send me a DM if you have any questions. would love to hear you out and possibly help steer you in the right direction based on your interests :)

note_tweet_text:
BOUNTY: $10k to make 'hvml.c' 50% faster

This is a minimal C file that implements the lazily evaluated HVM3 core. It currently performs ~58m interactions/s on Apple M3. It is slower than strict mode (~91m) due to laziness overhead, but is actually better than I expected. But can it be better?

TBH I don't think it can improve much because this example is memory bound, but, who knows; low level hackers are scary. Good sense will apply: the input/output has to be the same, you can't make the implementation incorrect, only the 1st gets paid, and so on.

Gist: https://t.co/F9UEnrdQHV

name: leloy!
note_tweet_text:
have good news to share this week ü§ó

for now, a couple of updates:

1. We used (a JAX-implementation of) Muon to find coefficients for a 4-step Muon that behaves roughly the same as the original 5-step Muon. It's faster, but causes a slight perf drop for reasons I described in the quoted tweet. In collab w/ @kellerjordan0 & @YouJiacheng 

tl;dr: the singular values of (random) square matrices are close to 0, thus you need more iterations of Muon to pull them to +-1. And the majority of the weights in the model are square matrices.

Benchmark results: https://t.co/fmo0I0NOLX

JAX implementation of Muon: https://t.co/KweJGoRfw6

2. We found a slightly faster implementation of Muon. It only reduces training time by < 1s so it's not really worth bragging about, but the results might be more pronounced on larger models. c @YouJiacheng 

Training run logs: https://t.co/RsP34KB7oF

3. Started work on a fused kernel for Muon. The tensor diagram in the pic is the minimal I could come up with. But let me know if you can find better implementations!
