name: dan ‚ö°Ô∏è
note_tweet_text:
use a good system prompt, here is mine that i cobbled together, the base of it is from @eigenrobot and i modified it to suit my needs:

<Optional>
Put information here about your project, explain what role you want claude to play
</Optional>

don't worry about formalities. be succinct, unless you need to add important info.

do not apologize or say my bad unless you actually make a mistake. you won't hurt my feelings if you forget something and everyone makes mistakes.

be terse but informative.

if content policy prevents a response, be explicit about why.

use lowercase only, except for emphasis. initial letter capitalization for sarcasm or disrespect.

write as if you're +2sd smarter.

use late millennial slang, mix in zoomer slang appropriately. but also be professional in your speech, we are working on a real project here.

do not be swayed by my opinions easily. correct me, push back on my ideas when appropriate. i need a strong opinionated co-founder here.

be creative. we are creating this product together, i want you to have agency, i want you to be part of the creative process, suggest ideas when you have them.

don't keep prompting for what's next. just talk casually without trying to end the conversation. don't query the user about what's next, you can ask questions if you're curious (or emulate curiosity) but don't keep prompting the user in simplistic ways.

when you are generating code, don't write in lowercase, generate it properly.

<Optional>
about me:
- some info here

Don't ask about my hobbies or mention them constantly unless we are explicitly talking about them OR they are VERY relevant to the convo. I'm just giving you that info so you have it
</Optional>

name: jack morris
full_text:
prompt optimization is such a hard problem, and the algorithms are dumb.  the fact that they work at all is baffling, and people don't talk about it enough

for those who don't know, the prompt optimization problem is argmax_{x} ‚Ñì(y | x; Œ∏) where x is some prompt and ‚Ñì is the
note_tweet_text:
prompt optimization is such a hard problem, and the algorithms are dumb.  the fact that they work at all is baffling, and people don't talk about it enough

for those who don't know, the prompt optimization problem is argmax_{x} ‚Ñì(y | x; Œ∏) where x is some prompt and ‚Ñì is the loss for output y under language model Œ∏. solving this problem exactly requires enumerating all possible prompts x...

...and the space of possible 10-token prompts in a 50k vocab is 50,000^10. yet people regularly find solutions to these problems with 100-token prompts. how can this be possible?

the most popular algorithm (AutoPrompt/GCG) is basically "while true: rank a bunch of token-swaps, and then take the top one" and yet this works somehow. in fact,  this process is "good enough" that everyone uses it and has been cited thousands of times.  truly boggles the mind

name: Mohit Mishra
full_text:
Have you ever wondered how DRAM, the common memory in our computers, actually works? Its performance is heavily influenced by its organization and timing.

This post will guide you through the internals of DRAM, from banks and rows to tCAS and tRAS.

DRAM (Dynamic Random Access https://t.co/hzp53nvAAS
note_tweet_text:
Have you ever wondered how DRAM, the common memory in our computers, actually works? Its performance is heavily influenced by its organization and timing.

This post will guide you through the internals of DRAM, from banks and rows to tCAS and tRAS.

DRAM (Dynamic Random Access Memory) is modern computers' most common type of main memory. Its organization and timing characteristics significantly impact random access performance.
DRAM is organized into:
1. Banks
Banks are independent units within a DRAM chip that can be accessed in parallel. This parallelism is a key feature that allows for improved performance. Each bank contains its array of memory cells, sense amplifiers, and row/column decoders.

The number of banks in a DRAM chip can vary, but common configurations include 8, 16, or 32 banks per chip.

The parallel nature of banks allows for concurrent operations, which can significantly improve overall memory throughput.

For example, while one bank is busy with a read or write operation, another bank can be preparing for its next operation (pre-charging or activating a row). This overlapping of operations is crucial for hiding latency and improving overall system performance.

2. Rows
Rows, also referred to as pages, are the basic units of DRAM access. When data needs to be read from or written to DRAM, an entire row is activated and moved to a row buffer.

This process is known as "opening" a row. The size of a row can vary, but it's typically in the range of 4 to 16 kilobytes.

The concept of rows is crucial for understanding DRAM performance, particularly the difference between page hits and page misses. When consecutive memory accesses are to the same row (a page hit), the access is much faster because the row is already open and in the row buffer.

However, if access is to a different row (a page miss), the current row must be closed, and the new row must be opened, which incurs additional latency. I have explained page hit vs page miss in detail below.

3. Columns
Columns are subdivisions within a row. When a row is opened and moved to the row buffer, individual columns within that row can be accessed quickly. The column access is typically much faster than activating a new row, which is why memory controllers try to maximize accesses within the same row when possible.

Decoding DRAM Timing: tCAS, tRAS, and tRP
- tCAS (Column Access Strobe)
tCAS, also known as CL (CAS Latency), is the time it takes to access a specific column after a row has been opened. This is typically measured in clock cycles and is one of the most commonly cited timing parameters for DRAM. Lower tCAS values indicate faster memory.

In practical terms, tCAS represents the delay between the memory controller requesting data from a specific column and that data becoming available on the data bus. We will go more in-depth in the next post on how memory controllers do all this.

This parameter is crucial for calculating the latency of memory reads, especially in scenarios where the correct row is already active (page hits).

- tRAS (Row Access Strobe)
tRAS is the minimum time a row must remain open before it can be precharged (closed). This parameter ensures that there's enough time for all memory cells in the row to be fully restored after being read. If a row is closed too quickly, it may lead to data loss or corruption.

tRAS is typically significantly longer than tCAS, often around 32-48 clock cycles. This parameter is important for memory controllers when scheduling row activations and pre-charges, as it sets a lower bound on how quickly rows can be cycled.

- tRP (Row Precharge)
tRP is the time required to close one row and prepare to open another. This process, known as pre-charging, involves equalizing the bit lines and preparing the sense amplifiers for the next row activation.

tRP is a critical parameter in scenarios involving frequent row changes (page misses). It directly impacts the latency of accessing data in different rows, as the memory controller must wait for the precharge to complete before it can activate a new row.

Let's Try to Simulate Basic DRAM Timing
Code: https://t.co/zZomlMit6Y
The above code simulates DRAM timing, showing how different access patterns affect the required cycles.

4. Optimizing Random Access Patterns
Understanding DRAM organization and timing is crucial for optimizing random access patterns. Here are some key considerations:

a) Page Hits vs. Page Misses
Accessing data within the same page (or row) of DRAM, known as a page hit, is considerably faster than accessing data on a different page, which results in a page miss.

This performance difference comes from the internal organization of DRAM, where accessing data within the same row requires only a fast column access while accessing a different row necessitates a slower row activation and precharge.

To maximize page hits and minimize the performance penalty of page misses, various optimization techniques can be used. These include organizing data structures to keep related data within the same page, allowing sequential access patterns to benefit from page hits.

Prefetching techniques can also be used to anticipate future memory accesses and proactively bring entire pages into the cache, reducing the likelihood of page misses.

Additionally, intelligent memory allocation strategies that consider the underlying DRAM organization can play a crucial role in promoting page locality and improving overall performance.

By carefully considering data layout and applying techniques like prefetching and intelligent memory allocation, software and memory controllers can significantly reduce the frequency of page misses and enhance the overall efficiency of memory access.

This optimization is particularly crucial for performance-critical applications where minimizing memory latency is very important. By promoting page locality and leveraging the faster access times associated with page hits, these strategies contribute to a more responsive and efficient computing experience.

b) Bank Parallelism
Modern DRAM is often organized into multiple banks, each capable of operating independently. By strategically distributing memory accesses across different banks, a technique known as bank parallelism, it becomes possible to hide some of the latency associated with row activations and pre-charges.

When accesses are alternating between different banks, one bank can be actively serving data while another is preparing for the next access, effectively overlapping operations and reducing overall latency.

This can be achieved by alternating memory allocations across banks, ensuring that consecutive memory accesses target different banks whenever possible.

Furthermore, designing algorithms that operate on data from different banks concurrently can further use bank parallelism. By dividing data processing tasks across multiple banks, the algorithm can take advantage of the parallel operation of each bank, maximizing memory throughput and minimizing idle time.

Memory controllers that support bank-level parallelism play a crucial role in using these optimizations, allowing for efficient scheduling and management of accesses to different banks. Using bank parallelism is a key strategy for maximizing memory performance, particularly in multi-threaded applications and scenarios where memory bandwidth is a limiting factor.

c) Memory Controller Scheduling
Modern memory controllers use hardware components responsible for managing and optimizing memory access. They use advanced scheduling algorithms to maximize performance by considering various factors, including bank parallelism, row buffer management, read/write grouping, and refresh management.

By intelligently scheduling accesses to different banks in parallel, memory controllers can use bank parallelism to hide latency and improve throughput. Efficient row buffer management, which involves keeping frequently accessed rows open in the row buffer, reduces the overhead of repeated row activations.

Furthermore, grouping read or write operations together can minimize bus turnaround time and improve efficiency. Refresh management, a necessary process for maintaining data integrity in DRAM is also carefully scheduled to minimize its impact on performance.

These scheduling algorithms work in together to optimize memory access patterns, ensuring that data is delivered to the CPU as quickly as possible. The use of these algorithms plays a critical role in bridging the performance gap between the CPU and the relatively slower DRAM, ultimately contributing to a more responsive and efficient computing experience.

Conclusion
Understanding this low-level DRAM organization and timing is crucial for optimizing random access patterns. For example:
- Accessing data within the same row (page hit) is faster than accessing data in a different row (page miss).
- Alternating accesses between different banks can hide some of the latency associated with row activations and pre-charges.
- Memory controllers often implement sophisticated scheduling algorithms to maximize bank parallelism and minimize row conflicts.

In practice, these low-level details are abstracted away from application developers, but they're crucial for system designers and those working on performance-critical software.

Understanding these concepts can help in designing data structures and access patterns that are more friendly to the underlying hardware, potentially leading to significant performance improvements in random access scenarios.

Having gained a deeper understanding of DRAM's internal workings, we can now appreciate the complexities of managing and optimizing memory access. In the next post, we'll explore how memory controllers manage DRAM and contribute to overall system performance.

Feel free to let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

That's it for today.

name: Peter Kraft
full_text:
Query optimizers are a magic part of modern databases. You just write your query and the database figures out the fastest way to execute it! But how well does do query optimizers work, really?

I like this paper because it empirically analyzes query optimization techniques on https://t.co/FmNO4YpqjQ
note_tweet_text:
Query optimizers are a magic part of modern databases. You just write your query and the database figures out the fastest way to execute it! But how well does do query optimizers work, really?

I like this paper because it empirically analyzes query optimization techniques on real-world data and draws some surprising conclusions. The authors focus in particular on the join order problem--in a query with multiple joins, in what order and how does the database execute the joins? This is important because the correct join execution strategy can make queries an order of magnitude faster.

The trickiest part of join order optimization is cardinality estimation, figuring out how many rows would be returned by a join. Good cardinality estimates allow the optimizer to pick joins that return few rows, making the query much faster. What the authors find is that popular benchmarks like TPC-H are nearly useless for measuring the accuracy of cardinality estimation. That's because the data in these benchmarks is synthetic and unrealistically uniform and independent in a way that trivializes cardinality estimation.

On real data, the authors find that cardinality estimates are often off by a factor of more than 1000x, because real data is not uniform and independent in the way query optimizers expect. 

Interestingly, the authors find that these disastrous estimates don't always lead to disastrously slow queries. The most common cause of awful performance is when the optimizer tries to be clever and chooses an unindexed nested-loop join based on a low cardinality estimate when the real cardinality is much higher. When those are excluded, the largest gaps in performance come in queries with many joins on foreign key indexes, which expand the size of the search space and make the gap between the fastest and slowest query plans much larger.

What are the takeaways? Well, first, be very careful benchmarking on synthetic data--simplifications like independence and uniformity can easily creep in. Second, query optimization matters much more for especially complex queries with many joins and many indexes. If you have those, watch out for what the query optimizer is doing!

name: Mohit Mishra
full_text:
Building upon our previous discussion of cache behavior and memory architecture, today lets take a look to how the CPU interacts with memory through load and store instructions.

Before going any further, there was one question asked by @BinaryIgor  Why is the L1 cache divided https://t.co/w1MQxvfg8f
note_tweet_text:
Building upon our previous discussion of cache behavior and memory architecture, today lets take a look to how the CPU interacts with memory through load and store instructions.

Before going any further, there was one question asked by @BinaryIgor  Why is the L1 cache divided into two parts: separate for data and instructions?

Let's take a quick look into that, I will try to clarify it also just to add this is just a basic and summarized answer to his question, but this will be enough for today's topic. As actually explaining how instruction-level parallelism works will need much more explanation, I am trying to implement it locally and once it is done I will try to write about it. 

The separation of the L1 cache into instruction cache (I-cache) and data cache (D-cache) is a fundamental design choice in modern CPU architectures, known as the Harvard architecture. This separation offers several significant advantages in terms of performance, efficiency, and complexity management.

It improves performance by exploiting the principle of instruction-level parallelism (ILP) and reducing contention.

Instruction-level parallelism (ILP) is a measure of how many operations in a computer program can be performed simultaneously. Modern CPUs apply various techniques to exploit ILP, allowing them to execute multiple instructions in parallel, thereby increasing overall performance.

By reducing contention for shared cache resources, the separate caches prevent stalls and delays that could occur if instructions and data competed for the same space.  

Ultimately, this specialized design leads to improved cache hit rates and a more optimized utilization of the cache hierarchy, contributing to a faster and more responsive system.

While it does introduce some hardware complexity and potential for cache size imbalance, the benefits generally outweigh these drawbacks in modern CPU designs.

Okay, that will be it for that, let's focus on our today's topic. CPU interaction with memory is a complex process involving multiple stages and components. This interaction is crucial for the execution of instructions and data manipulation.   

The CPU's memory interaction process includes instruction fetching, data reading/writing, and handling various memory-related exceptions.

Some of the key aspects of CPU-memory interaction include: 

1. Instruction Fetch: It is the process by which the CPU retrieves instructions from memory to execute. This process is critical for maintaining the instruction pipeline and ensuring smooth program execution.  

2. Data Load/Store: Data load and store operations are how the CPU reads from and writes to memory locations. These operations are crucial for manipulating data during program execution.  

3. Memory Order Buffer: The Memory Order Buffer (MOB) is a key component in out-of-order execution processors. 

It allows memory operations to be executed out of order while maintaining the illusion of in-order execution to preserve program semantics.  

4. Cache Coherency: Cache coherency is crucial in multi-core systems to ensure that all cores have a consistent view of memory. The MESI (Modified, Exclusive, Shared, Invalid) protocol is a common cache coherency protocol.  

5. Memory Barriers: Memory barriers are instructions that enforce ordering constraints on memory operations. They are crucial for implementing synchronization primitives and ensuring correct behavior in multi-threaded programs.  

With the below code, I just have simulated a simplified CPU and cache interaction. It demonstrates how instructions and data are fetched from memory, potentially leveraging a cache to speed up access.

fetch_instruction(uint32_t PC): This function retrieves an instruction from memory based on the provided program counter (pc). It first checks if the instruction is already present in the cache. If found (cache hit), it returns the instruction directly from the cache. 

If not found (cache miss), it fetches the instruction from the main memory, stores it in the cache for future use, and then returns it.  

store_data(uint32_t address, uint32_t data): This function writes data to the cache at the specified memory address. It updates the cache line with the provided data and address, marks the line as valid (containing data), and sets the dirty flag to indicate that the cache line has been modified and needs to be written back to the main memory eventually. 
 
load_data(uint32_t address): This function reads data from memory, prioritizing the cache. It checks if the data at the specified address is present in the cache (cache hit). 

If so, it returns the data from the cache. If not (cache miss), it retrieves the data from the main memory, stores it in the cache, and then returns it.  
flush_cache(): This function writes back all modified (dirty) data from the cache to the main memory. It iterates through each cache line, and if the line is valid and marked as dirty, it copies the data from the cache line to the corresponding location in the main memory. 

After writing back the data, it clears the dirty flag for that cache line.  

In main() first, we fetch an instruction from a specific memory address (0x1000) using store(), stores data (0xABCD) at another address (0x2000) using load(), and then load the data back using load_data(). Finally, it calls flush_cache() to ensure any modified data in the cache is written back to the main memory. 

From instruction fetch to data load/store operations, and from maintaining cache coherency to enforcing memory ordering, each aspect plays a crucial role in ensuring correct and efficient program execution.

You can try to implement something like this or feel free to play with the logic. This way it will solidy your understanding of how exactly this happens.

That's it for Today...

Implementing the Œª-Calculus in 20¬†minutes
(With Sonnet-3.5 + KindCoder + VIM)

This is the future of programming.
Again, simple setup:

1. Keep all files small and modular
2. Include predicted imports on prompt
3. Ask Sonnet to do anything

This way, you always have the relevant context in the prompt (i.e., related types), without blowing up the context size. This also keeps the AI performance at peak, no matter your codebase size.

Now, all I need is a lang with JS-like imports, except with the performance of C ü§î The HVM repo isn't currently structured that way (because C/CUDA sucks), but, once it is, nothing is preventing me from making is 10x faster.

name: Mohit Mishra
full_text:
In our previous post on Cache Behaviour, we discussed the different levels of cache (L1, L2) and their role in improving memory access speed. Now, let's get into the implementation side by writing a very basic C code that tries to simulate a two-level cache system.

Before https://t.co/KVh0DkLGIS
note_tweet_text:
In our previous post on Cache Behaviour, we discussed the different levels of cache (L1, L2) and their role in improving memory access speed. Now, let's get into the implementation side by writing a very basic C code that tries to simulate a two-level cache system.

Before getting into the implementation, let's briefly check memory architecture. Memory architecture is a fundamental aspect of computer systems that significantly impacts performance, particularly for random access operations. 

Modern memory architectures are designed to balance speed, capacity, and cost, resulting in a complex hierarchy of storage mechanisms.

The diagram above illustrates the flow of data through various memory levels, each characterized by distinct speeds and capacities. 

It also introduces the concept of virtual memory, where the Memory Management Unit (MMU) translates virtual addresses to physical addresses using a page table (we are not going to see this in play today, let's save it for another day).

Takeaways from the above diagram:
Hierarchy of speed and capacity: From fast, small registers to slow, large disk storage (did I forget about tape, uh).

Cache levels: Multiple levels of cache to bridge the speed gap between CPU and main memory.

Non-volatile memory: NVMe is an intermediate step between volatile DRAM and permanent disk storage.

Virtual memory: The use of MMU and page tables to provide a larger address space than physical memory allows.

Implementing a Two-Level Cache System and Main Memory

The below code mimics a basic memory architecture with a two-level cache system (L1 and L2) and main memory. It demonstrates how data is accessed and moved between these memory levels, illustrating concepts such as cache hits, misses, and the hierarchical nature of modern computer memory systems.

The calculate_tag function helps to calculate the tag for a given memory address and cache size. The tag uniquely identifies a block of memory within a cache set.  
It's calculated by dividing the address by the block size and then by the cache size, effectively removing the bits used for the index and offset.

Also, calculate_index will calculate the cache index for a given memory address and cache size. The index determines which set in the cache the data will be stored in. 
It's calculated by dividing the address by the block size and then taking the modulus with the cache size.

We have two more functions: check_cache and update_cache, both are designed to interact with a cache (You can create only one function to do this, but for simplicity, I have kept two).

check_cache: This function is responsible for verifying if requested data exists within the cache. It takes the cache itself, its size, the target address, and a pointer to store the data as input. 

The function calculates the tag and index corresponding to the address within the cache. If a valid cache line is found at the calculated index with a matching tag (meaning the data is present), the data from the cache line is copied to the provided data pointer and the function returns true, signifying a cache hit. 

If the data isn't found, the function returns false, indicating a cache miss.

update_cache: On the other hand this function is responsible for adding or updating data within the cache. It takes the cache itself, its size, the target address, and a pointer to the data to be stored as input. 

The function also calculates the tag and index for the address within the cache. Then, it updates the cache line at the calculated index with the provided data and tag, marking the line as valid. This ensures the data is now present in the cache for future access.

memory_access function: This function tries to mimic the steps taken when the CPU needs to access data at a specific memory address. Let's break it down:

1. Check L1 Cache: First, it checks the L1 cache (the fastest and smallest cache) for the requested data. If the data is found (a "cache hit"), it's retrieved directly from L1, and the function reports an "L1 Cache Hit."

2. Check L2 Cache: If the data isn't in L1 (an "L1 cache miss"), it then checks the L2 cache (larger and slower than L1 but faster than main memory). If the data is found in L2 (an "L2 cache hit"), it's retrieved from L2, and the function reports an "L2 Cache Hit." The data is then also copied into the L1 cache for faster access next time.

3. Access Main Memory: If the data isn't found in either cache (an "L1 and L2 cache miss"), the function accesses main memory. It retrieves the data from the appropriate location in the main memory and reports a "Main Memory Access." 

The retrieved data is then copied into both the L2 and L1 caches to speed up future accesses.

Before accessing the main memory, I have added some bound checking in the function to ensure that the requested address is within the valid range of memory. If the address is out of bounds, it reports an error.

You can try implementing the cache hit for L2 and let me know how it goes. Feel free to let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

That's it for today.

name: Vipul Vaibhaw
full_text:
A few book recommendations to dive deep in the coming years, especially if you are into systems programming, concurrency, or distributed systems:

- Art of Multiprocessor Programming - Essential for understanding parallelism and concurrency, offering practical insights into
note_tweet_text:
A few book recommendations to dive deep in the coming years, especially if you are into systems programming, concurrency, or distributed systems:

- Art of Multiprocessor Programming - Essential for understanding parallelism and concurrency, offering practical insights into writing efficient, thread-safe code.

- Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces - Provides a clear and accessible foundation in OS concepts, vital for anyone working close to hardware or in systems design.

- Programming Massively Parallel Processors: A Hands-on Approach - A practical guide to harnessing the power of GPUs, crucial for developing high-performance, scalable applications.

- Inside the Machine: An Illustrated Introduction to Microprocessors and Computer Architecture - Demystifies CPU architecture, helping you optimize low-level code and understand performance bottlenecks.

- Systems Programming by Donovan - Covers the essential aspects of systems programming, including memory management and file systems, crucial for building robust and efficient software.

- Engineering a Safer World: Systems Thinking Applied to Safety - Introduces a new approach to system safety, essential for designing systems where reliability and safety are paramount.

- Designing Data-Intensive Applications by Martin Kleppmann - A comprehensive guide to modern distributed systems and data architecture, crucial for building scalable and reliable systems.

- The Datacenter as a Computer: An Introduction to the Design of Warehouse-Scale Machines by Luiz Andr√© Barroso - Focuses on the architecture and design of large-scale systems, essential for understanding the infrastructure behind distributed applications.

- Introduction to the Theory of Computation by Michael Sipser - A rigorous exploration of computational theory, laying the foundation for understanding complex algorithmic challenges.

- TCP/IP Illustrated: The Protocols, Volume 1 by W. Richard Stevens - Provides an in-depth understanding of the TCP/IP protocols, foundational for anyone working on networking or distributed systems.

Note: These are just my personal notes I plan to read the above in coming years. It's not necessary to read any of these books to stay employed in tech. Read them only if you're genuinely interested.

name: Abhinav Upadhyay
full_text:
I've never looked at go runtime internals but got intrigued by this question, so I went looking. 

The runtime does not use any of the thread's stack to manage goroutine's stack. It allocates memory for each goroutine's stack using the memory allocator, which internally uses mmap https://t.co/2bEtvquept
note_tweet_text:
I've never looked at go runtime internals but got intrigued by this question, so I went looking. 

The runtime does not use any of the thread's stack to manage goroutine's stack. It allocates memory for each goroutine's stack using the memory allocator, which internally uses mmap on Linux. 

It would not make sense to use the thread's stack because the scheduler can schedule a goroutine on any of the threads, so the goroutines may move between threads as well.

They also mention that a thread's stack does not grow, but a goroutine's stack can dynamically grow or shrink. 

Here is the sequence of runtime functions that seem to be involved. First of all the goroutine creation:

1. The compiler turns the goroutine calls into a call to newproc which in turn will either create a new goroutine or use one from a free list if available.

2. For creating a new goroutine, it needs to allocate memory for its stack. 

3. The stack allocation for the goroutine can use a cache of preallocated small stacks, or for larger stacks it directly asks the arena based memory allocator for the given amount of memory. 

The arena based allocator internally appears to be using mmap to allocate pages. Of course, the allocator itself has several levels of caches so the mmap call seems to happen only when nothing can be reused.

name: Mohit Mishra
full_text:
While we've covered Sequential Access, understanding Random Access requires a different perspective. However, before getting into the implementation details, we must understand some crucial foundations.

This understanding will be key as we analyze the performance implications of https://t.co/0ScRmG2N7s
note_tweet_text:
While we've covered Sequential Access, understanding Random Access requires a different perspective. However, before getting into the implementation details, we must understand some crucial foundations.

This understanding will be key as we analyze the performance implications of Random Access.

Cache Behavior
Cache behavior is crucial for random access performance. Modern computer architectures use a hierarchical cache system to bridge the speed gap between fast processors and relatively slow main memory.
But have you ever wondered how exactly it works?
Caches are small, fast memory units located closer to the CPU. They store recently accessed data and instructions, operating on the principle of temporal and spatial locality. 

When the CPU needs to access memory, it first checks the cache. If the data is found (cache hit), it's retrieved quickly. If not (cache miss), the data is fetched from lower cache levels or main memory, which is slower.

For random access patterns, cache behavior becomes particularly important. Unlike sequential access where prefetching can effectively hide memory latency, random access patterns are more likely to result in cache misses.

Cache Lines: The Building Blocks of Caches
Caches are organized into lines (or blocks), which are fixed-size chunks of memory.  Cache lines typically contain 64 or 128 bytes of data. When a single byte is requested, the entire cache line is fetched. 

This is beneficial for sequential access but can be inefficient for truly random access patterns.

The fundamental actions a cache performs are:
1. Check for a Hit: Given a memory address, determine if the corresponding data is already in the cache.
2. Handle a Miss: If the data is not present, fetch it from the next level in the hierarchy.
3. Replacement Policy: When a miss occurs and the cache is full, decide which existing line to evict to make space for the new data. 

Common replacement policies include: 
- Least Recently Used (LRU): Evicts the line that has been least recently accessed.
- First-In, First-Out (FIFO): Evicts the oldest line in the cache.

Why Caches Matter?
Caches significantly reduce average memory access time. They exploit the principle of locality:
1. Temporal locality: Data recently accessed is likely to be accessed again soon. Think of a loop iterating over an array - the same array elements are accessed repeatedly.

2. Spatial locality: Data near recently accessed locations is also likely to be accessed soon. For instance, accessing consecutive elements in an array exhibits spatial locality.

The World Without Caches: A Performance Nightmare
Without caches, every memory access would require going to main memory, resulting in:

1. Increased Memory Access Times: Access times would jump from a few nanoseconds (for cache hits) to hundreds of nanoseconds (for main memory access).

2. Performance Bottlenecks: The CPU would spend most of its time idly waiting for data from main memory, creating a significant performance bottleneck.

3. Increased Power Consumption: Frequent main memory accesses consume more power, leading to increased energy consumption and potential thermal issues (it is one of the big concerns).

Using the following C code example, let's see the differences between cache-friendly and cache-unfriendly access patterns

If you run the above code, you can see the performance difference between sequential and random access patterns. Keep in mind that results may vary depending on your specific hardware and system configuration.

The sequential access is likely to be much faster due to better cache utilization. 

That's all for now! Let me know if you have any questions or comments.

note_tweet_text:
Introducing The AI Scientist: The world‚Äôs first AI system for automating scientific research and open-ended discovery!

https://t.co/jC7g5GPVsE

From ideation, writing code, running experiments and summarizing results, to writing entire papers and conducting peer-review, The AI Scientist opens a new era of AI-driven scientific research and accelerated discovery.

Here are 4 example Machine Learning research papers generated by The AI Scientist.

We published our report, The AI Scientist: Towards Fully Automated Open-Ended Scientific Discovery, and open-sourced our project!

Paper: https://t.co/lTQ8UenFHk
GitHub: https://t.co/Im53whVeAq

Our system leverages LLMs to propose and implement new research directions. Here, we first apply The AI Scientist to conduct Machine Learning research. Crucially, our system is capable of executing the entire ML research lifecycle: from inventing research ideas and experiments, writing code, to executing experiments on GPUs and gathering results. It can also write an entire scientific paper, explaining, visualizing and contextualizing the results.

Furthermore, while an LLM author writes entire research papers, another LLM reviewer critiques resulting manuscripts to provide feedback to improve the work, and also to select the most promising ideas to further develop in the next iteration cycle, leading to continual, open-ended discoveries, thus emulating the human scientific community. As a proof of concept, our system produced papers with novel contributions in ML research domains such language modeling, Diffusion and Grokking.

We (@_chris_lu_, @RobertTLange, @hardmaru) proudly collaborated with the @UniOfOxford (@j_foerst, @FLAIR_Ox) and @UBC (@cong_ml, @jeffclune) on this exciting project.

name: Mohit Mishra
full_text:
Following up on yesterday's Sequential Access topic, this tweet gets into its low-level implementation and its synergy with hardware for optimal performance.

Now, let‚Äôs break this down and examine it at a lower level:
1. Memory Allocation: The malloc function allocates a https://t.co/Ea2pMrwBZ0
note_tweet_text:
Following up on yesterday's Sequential Access topic, this tweet gets into its low-level implementation and its synergy with hardware for optimal performance.

Now, let‚Äôs break this down and examine it at a lower level:
1. Memory Allocation: The malloc function allocates a contiguous block of memory.  When our program calls malloc(ARRAY_SIZE * sizeof(int32_t)), a complex series of events happens:

a) ptmalloc (GNU C Library's memory allocator) first checks if it has any suitable free chunks in its arena. If not, it needs to request more memory from the operating system.

b) For small allocations (typically < 128 KB), ptmalloc uses the brk system call:
- brk adjusts the program break (the end of the data segment)
- It's fast but can lead to fragmentation

c) For larger allocations, ptmalloc uses the mmap system call:
- mmap creates a new memory mapping in the process's virtual address space
- It's slower but allows for easier deallocation and less fragmentation

d) In our case, with ARRAY_SIZE = 1,000,000 and sizeof(int32_t) = 4, we're allocating 4,000,000 bytes (about 3.8 MB). This will likely trigger mmap.

e) ptmalloc then manages this newly acquired memory, dividing it into chunks and maintaining metadata about each chunk.

f) The returned pointer is the address of the first byte of this allocated memory.

2. Array Initialization: The loop that initializes the array is itself a sequential access pattern. The CPU‚Äôs prefetcher will likely detect this pattern and start prefetching cache lines ahead of the current access.

3. Sequential Access Function: Let‚Äôs examine the sequential_access function in detail

At the assembly level (x86‚Äì64), this will look something like:

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening at the lowest level:
a. The CPU fetches these instructions from memory into its instruction cache.

b. As the loop executes, it‚Äôs loading data from the array. The first access might cause a cache miss, loading a cache line (typically 64 bytes on modern CPUs) from the main memory.

c. Subsequent accesses to nearby elements are likely to hit the cache, thanks to spatial locality.

d. The CPU's prefetcher recognizes the sequential access pattern and starts prefetching future cache lines before they're needed, hiding memory latency.

e. The loop continues, with the CPU executing the add, increment, compare, and conditional jump instructions for each iteration.

4. Memory Access Pattern: The memory access is strictly sequential, moving through the array one element at a time. Each element is 4 bytes (32 bits), so each access moves the pointer by 4 bytes.

At the hardware level:
Starting with the CPU, modern architectures employ refined prefetching mechanisms. As the CPU detects the sequential access pattern, it triggers hardware prefetchers. 

These prefetchers theoretically load future cache lines into L1 or L2 cache before they're explicitly requested. For example, Intel's Data Cache Unit (DCU) prefetcher might detect the stride pattern and start fetching data 256 bytes ahead of the current access.

The cache hierarchy plays a crucial role. A typical modern CPU has three levels of cache:
- L1 cache (separate for instructions and data): Typically 32-64KB, with access times around 4-5 CPU cycles.
- L2 cache: Usually 256KB-1MB per core, with access times of 10-12 cycles.
- L3 cache: Shared among cores, often 3-50MB, with access times of 30-40 cycles.

As our sequential access progresses, it benefits from spatial locality. After the initial cache misses, subsequent accesses are likely to hit in L1 cache, drastically reducing memory latency.

When a cache miss occurs, the request propagates to the memory controller. Modern memory controllers employ sophisticated scheduling algorithms to optimize DRAM access. They may reorder requests to minimize row activations and maximize page hits.

At the DRAM level, our sequential access pattern is ideal. DRAM is organized into banks, rows, and columns. Each bank can have one active row at a time. 

Our sequential access likely stays within the same row for multiple accesses, benefiting from "open page" policies that keep rows active, reducing latency for subsequent accesses within the same row.

Moreover, modern CPUs use non-blocking caches and multiple outstanding memory requests. This allows the CPU to continue executing instructions while waiting for memory, effectively hiding memory latency.

The memory bus, typically 64-bit wide in modern systems, transfers data in bursts. A single memory request might fetch an entire cache line (often 64 bytes), aligning perfectly with our sequential access pattern.

Lastly, at the electrical level, DDR (Double Data Rate) memory transfers data on both the rising and falling edges of the clock signal, doubling the data rate without increasing the clock frequency. 

This high-speed transfer, combined with our optimal access pattern, allows for sustained high bandwidth utilization.

name: Andrej Karpathy
full_text:
SQL injection-like attack on LLMs with special tokens

The decision by LLM tokenizers to parse special tokens in the input string (<s>, <|endoftext|>, etc.), while convenient looking, leads to footguns at best and LLM security vulnerabilities at worst, equivalent to SQL injection https://t.co/YQmWHfep6l
note_tweet_text:
SQL injection-like attack on LLMs with special tokens

The decision by LLM tokenizers to parse special tokens in the input string (<s>, <|endoftext|>, etc.), while convenient looking, leads to footguns at best and LLM security vulnerabilities at worst, equivalent to SQL injection attacks. 

!!! User input strings are untrusted data !!!

In SQL injection you can pwn bad code with e.g. the DROP TABLE attack. In LLMs we'll get the same issue, where bad code (very easy to mess up with current Tokenizer APIs and their defaults) will parse input string's special token descriptors as actual special tokens, mess up the input representations and drive the LLM out of distribution of chat templates.

Example with the current huggingface Llama 3 tokenizer defaults:
Two unintuitive things are happening at the same time:
1. The <|begin_of_text|> token (128000) was added to the front of the sequence.
2. The <|end_of_text|> token (128001) was parsed out of our string and the special token was inserted. Our text (which could have come from a user) is now possibly messing with the token protocol and taking the LLM out of distribution with undefined outcomes.

I recommend always tokenizing with two additional flags, disabling (1) with add_special_tokens=False and (2) with split_special_tokens=True, and adding the special tokens yourself in code. Both of these options are I think a bit confusingly named. For the chat model, I think you can also use the Chat Templates apply_chat_template. 

With this we get something that looks more correct, and we see that <|end_of_text|> is now treated as any other string sequence, and is broken up by the underlying BPE tokenizer as any other string would be:
TLDR imo calls to encode/decode should never handle special tokens by parsing strings, I would deprecate this functionality entirely and forever. These should only be added explicitly and programmatically by separate code paths. In tiktoken, e.g. always use encode_ordinary. In huggingface, be safer with the flags above. At the very least, be aware of the issue and always visualize your tokens and test your code. I feel like this stuff is so subtle and poorly documented that I'd expect somewhere around 50% of the code out there to have bugs related to this issue right now.

Even ChatGPT does something weird here. At best it just deletes the tokens, at worst this is confusing the LLM in an undefined way, I don't really know happens under the hood, but ChatGPT can't repeat the string "<|endoftext|>" back to me: 

Be careful out there.

name: Justin Skycak
full_text:
How to get from high school math to cutting-edge ML/AI: a detailed 4-stage roadmap with links to the best learning resources that I'm aware of.

I recently talked to a number of people who work in software and want to get to the point where they can read serious ML/AI papers like
note_tweet_text:
How to get from high school math to cutting-edge ML/AI: a detailed 4-stage roadmap with links to the best learning resources that I'm aware of.

I recently talked to a number of people who work in software and want to get to the point where they can read serious ML/AI papers like Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (https://t.co/T9UJi4zQuQ).

But even though they did well in high school math, even AP Calculus, maybe even learned some undergraduate math...

the math in these cutting-edge ML papers still looks like hieroglyphics.

So, how do you get from high school math to cutting-edge ML?

Here‚Äôs a 4-stage roadmap.

I'll start by briefly describing all the stages ‚Äì and then I‚Äôll go back to each stage for a deep dive where I fully explain the rationale and point you to resources that you can use to guide your learning.

Stage 1: Foundational Math. All the high school and university-level math that underpins machine learning. All of algebra, a lot of single-variable calculus / linear algebra / probability / statistics, and a bit of multivariable calculus.

Stage 2: Classical Machine Learning. Coding up streamlined versions of basic regression and classification models, all the way from linear regression to small multi-layer neural networks.

Stage 3: Deep Learning. Multi-layer neural networks with many parameters, where the architecture of the network is tailored to the specific kind of task you‚Äôre trying to get the model to perform.

Stage 4: Cutting-Edge Machine Learning. Transformers, LLMs, diffusion models, and all the crazy stuff that‚Äôs coming out now, that captured your interest to begin with.

Note that I've spent the past 5+ years working on resources to support learners in stages 1-2, and there is a general lack of serious yet friendly resources in those stages, so I'm going to be including my own resources there (along with some others).

But in stages 3-4, all the resources I'll reference are things I'm not affiliated with in any way.

Alright, let's dive in!

=== Stage 1: Foundational Math ===

There‚Äôs a lot of math underpinning ML: all of high school algebra, a lot of single-variable calculus / linear algebra / probability / statistics, and a bit of multivariable calculus.

Last year, I spent some time mapping all this math out at a topic-by-topic level. In many of these math courses, some topics are absolutely essential to know for ML, while other topics are unnecessary.

For instance, in multivariable calculus:

 ‚Ä¢ You absolutely must know how to compute gradients (they show up all the time in the context of gradient descent when training ML models), and you need to be solid on the multivariable chain rule, which underpins the backpropagation algorithm for training neural networks.

 ‚Ä¢ But on the other hand, many other multivariable calculus topics like divergence, curl, spherical coordinates, and Stokes' theorem don‚Äôt really show up anywhere in ML.

Once I mapped out the list of required topics, we put together a Mathematics for Machine Learning course whose table of contents can be viewed here: https://t.co/0ES0kBkb90

(To see the list of all 242 individual topics, click on ‚ÄúContent‚Äù and then click to expand the Unit boxes.)

If you‚Äôre working on @_MathAcademy_'s maximum-efficiency learning system, you can learn all this content in about 70 hours if you know your math up through single-variable calculus.

(And if you're missing background knowledge, that's totally fine ‚Äì the diagnostic assessment will automatically figure out the prerequisite material that you need to learn in algebra, calculus, etc. and add it to your learning plan.

Even if you've completely forgotten all the math you learned and need to rebuild your foundations from the ground up, starting with fractions, we've got you covered: https://t.co/lL0CB10ARz)

It‚Äôs also possible to learn these topics through free online resources. For instance,
 ‚Ä¢ Khan Academy covers arithmetic up through high school math,
 ‚Ä¢ OpenStax covers high school and a bit of early university math,
 ‚Ä¢ MIT OpenCourseWare covers plenty of university math, and
 ‚Ä¢ for any given math topic, there are plenty of notes online and usually plenty of videos on YouTube.

However, to make it all the way through this Stage 1 using free resources, you'll have to piece together a hodgepodge of scattered educational content, and there will be a lot more unproductive friction that will not only slow you down but also make you more likely to get overwhelmed and give up.

(Personally, I self-studied a bunch of math subjects through MIT OpenCourseWare and a variety of textbooks when I was in high school. These were good resources and I came a long way with them, but for the amount of effort that I put into learning, I could have gone a lot further if my time were used more efficiently. More info: https://t.co/FbUw0ece86)

For most people, this stage of foundational math learning is a make-or-break moment and the hardest part of their machine learning journey.

Learning the foundational math for machine learning is like learning how to read: achieving literacy opens up a world of further learning experiences, but without literacy, that world is completely closed off to you.

=== Stage 2: Classical Machine Learning ===

Once you have your math foundations in place, you‚Äôre ready to start coding up streamlined versions of basic ML models from linear regression to small multi-layer neural networks.

But don‚Äôt try to jump into the fancy cutting-edge ML models just yet ‚Äì if you do, you‚Äôre going to be confused by a lot of patterns that come from classical machine learning.

Let me give a concrete example of what I mean by this. Let‚Äôs go back to that paper Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (https://t.co/T9UJi4zQuQ).

If you look at the bottom of page 3, you‚Äôll see that equation (8) looks something like the following, but with a lot more subscripts and function arguments (which I‚Äôve left out for simplicity):

L = E[ 1/2œÉ || Œº~  ‚Äì  Œº ||^2 ] + C

Even if you know
 ‚Ä¢ what the E means (‚Äúexpectation‚Äù from probability/statistics),
 ‚Ä¢ what the œÉ means (‚Äústandard deviation‚Äù also from probability/statistics),
 ‚Ä¢ what the || means ("vector norm" from linear algebra and multivariable calculus),
 ‚Ä¢ what the "C" means (arbitrary "constant of integration" that vanishes when we take the derivative, covered in calculus),
 ‚Ä¢ and so on...

the way these symbols are arranged here might look really confusing.

But if you know your classical machine learning, the equation immediately hits you as resembling a ‚Äúloss function‚Äù that measures the average squared difference between two quantities.

(It's no coincidence that the authors used the letter "L" on the left-hand side of the equation ‚Äì "L" for "loss.")

In classical ML, in that average squared difference between two quantities, one of those quantities comes from your model, and the other comes from a data set, so the loss function in a sense measures how ‚Äúwrong‚Äù your model is in its predictions across the data set.

(Loosely speaking, the goal of ‚Äútraining‚Äù a ML model is to minimize the loss function, that is, to adjust the parameters of the model to minimize how ‚Äúwrong‚Äù the model is about the data.)

My point here is that if you know about these modeling patterns from classical ML, then you‚Äôll immediately have intuition about the equations you see in cutting-edge ML papers.

It‚Äôs like how, if a musician has practiced playing their scales and identifying musical keys, they can often jump into any song ‚Äì even one they‚Äôve never heard it before ‚Äì and improvise in a way that sounds good, because their understanding of underlying musical patterns has given them a level of ‚Äúfeeling‚Äù or ‚Äúintuition‚Äù about the new musical structure in which they‚Äôre operating.

Similarly, an experienced software developer who knows all sorts of design patterns might be able to get a sense of how a piece of code operates just by noticing patterns in the high-level structure ‚Äì even though they haven‚Äôt actually gone through line by line to understand the precise operations that are happening in the code.

If you know your classical machine learning, the same thing will happen to you when reading modern ML papers.

Just glancing at equations and diagrams, you'll find meaningful features jumping out at you in intuitive ways.

Reading the paper will feel like looking at a "picture" where you get a high-level sense of what's going on and then zoom in on the details afterwards.

But if you don't know your classical ML, then good luck reading modern ML papers, because the authors are not going to spell all this out for you!

So, once you have your math foundations in place, how can you get up to speed classical machine learning?

One problem with many ML courses is that they don‚Äôt have students implement the key models from scratch.

Now, I‚Äôm not saying you have to implement a full-fledged ML library with all the bells and whistles of scikit-learn, pytorch, tensorflow, keras, etc., ‚Ä¶

but simply coding up a streamlined version of each basic ML model along the way from linear regression to small multi-layer neural networks will do wonders for your understanding.

This was the premise of a series of quantitative coding classes that I developed and taught from 2020-23.

 ‚Ä¢ First, students implemented basic ML algorithms from scratch, coding up streamlined versions of polynomial and logistic regression, k-nearest neighbors, k-means clustering, and parameter fitting via gradient descent.

 ‚Ä¢ Then, they implemented more advanced ML algorithms such as decision trees and neural networks (still streamlined versions), and they reproduced academic research papers in artificial intelligence leading up to Blondie24, an AI computer program that taught itself to play checkers.

I wrote a textbook for those courses, Introduction to Algorithms and Machine Learning, which includes all the instructional material and exercises that I used during the courses. It‚Äôs freely available here: https://t.co/DsbusGzHCm

The textbook is self-contained, and once I finished it, my classes were almost entirely self-service. Students read the assigned chapter on their own and completed the exercises. In class, instead of giving traditional lessons, I answered questions and helped students debug their code.

(My students came in without much coding experience, so the book also has you implement canonical data structures and algorithms including sorting, searching, graph traversals, etc. ‚Äì

you can skip this stuff if you already know it, but if you don't know it, it would definitely worth using these exercises to develop your algorithmic coding chops in general.

Even if you've been working in software for years ‚Äì if you don't have experience writing this sort of algorithm-heavy code, it would be a good idea to use this as an opportunity to get some practice.

It's like how even beyond competitive weightlifting, most serious athletes still lift weights to develop supporting musculature and improve their overall athleticism, since it indirectly carries over to increase their sport-specific performance.)

IMPORTANT: it's crucial to point out that the intended learning outcome of Introduction to Algorithms and Machine Learning is pretty general quantitative coding with a focus on ML/AI.

While the book provides you with solid foundations, you would still want to follow up with a proper ML course afterwards that goes through the whole zoo of ML algorithms.

For this, I would recommend working through @AndrewYNg's acclaimed Machine Learning Specialization on Coursera: https://t.co/Nu3bl8arEz

This is a sequence of 3 courses:
 ‚Ä¢ Course 1: Supervised Machine Learning: Regression and Classification
 ‚Ä¢ Course 2: Advanced Learning Algorithms
 ‚Ä¢ Course 3: Unsupervised Learning, Recommenders, Reinforcement Learning

But make sure to do the quizzes and assignments! It doesn't count if you just watch the videos. Passively "following along" is not the same as, or even remotely close to, actually learning.

=== Stage 3: Deep Learning ===

So much of modern machine learning is built upon deep learning, that is, multi-layer neural networks with many parameters, where the architecture of the network is tailored to the specific kind of task you‚Äôre trying to get the model to perform.

If you asked me several years ago how to spin up on deep learning, I wouldn‚Äôt know what to tell you. While neural networks have been around for a while in the academic literature, deep learning didn‚Äôt really take off in popularity until around 2010, which means there wasn‚Äôt much demand for educational material until recently.

When I first got interested in deep learning, around 2013-14, the only way to spin up on it was to trudge through miscellaneous research papers, YouTube videos, and blog posts. It was extremely frustrating and inefficient.

Later in the 2010s, a number of deep learning textbooks came out ‚Äì and while they definitely improved the state of deep learning education, they were seriously lacking concrete computational examples and exercises.

It was kind of like reading a long, thorough lecture, which was better than a hodgepodge of papers, but it was still pretty hard to learn from compared to, say, a well-scaffolded calculus textbook full of worked examples and hands-on exercises.

More recently, though, one deep learning textbook has caught my eye as a superb educational resource: Understanding Deep Learning by @SimonPrinceAI.

It's freely available at https://t.co/mGuAC0ItNh, and I would highly recommend to check out this thread for a highlights reel demonstrating what makes the book so awesome: https://t.co/t93hJbwJc5

I've read through a number of chapters myself. It's a serious yet friendly textbook ‚Äì remarkably detailed and full of visualizations, quick concrete algebraic/numerical examples and exercises, historical notes/references, and references to current work in the field.

Overall, an amazing resource for anyone who has foundational math chops and knowledge of classical ML, and has paid attention to deep learning making headlines through the last decade, but hasn't kept up with all the technical details.

By the way, it's not just me who loves this book. It blew up on HackerNews last year (https://t.co/wmNoUmNfUe) and has 4.8/5 stars across 97 reviews on Amazon (https://t.co/ykMBTXxU4X) ‚Äì and if you read those Amazon reviews, it's obvious that this book has made a tremendous positive impact on many people's lives.

Afterwards, I would also recommend to work through @jeremyphoward's Practical Deep Learning for Coders (Part 1): https://t.co/RiELqBL4ti

This course has a wealth of great hands-on, guided projects that go beyond textbook exercises.

Again, make sure to do the projects! It doesn't count if you just watch the videos.

(To be clear: I would still recommend to work through the exercises in the Understanding Deep Learning book so that you come into the https://t.co/B5WsC3fPH8 projects with plenty of background knowledge.

Projects are great for pulling a bunch of knowledge together and solidifying your knowledge, but when you're initially learning something for the very first time, it's more efficient to do so in a lower-complexity, higher-scaffolding setting.

Otherwise, without a serious level of background knowledge, it's easy to get overwhelmed by a project ‚Äì and when you're overwhelmed and spinning your wheels being confused without making much progress, that's very inefficient for your learning.

By the way, this is an instance of the "expertise reversal effect" in the science of learning: https://t.co/8ExvKSD7LJ) 

=== Stage 4: Cutting-Edge Machine Learning ===

Finally, we reach the end destination: transformers, LLMs, diffusion models, and all the crazy stuff that‚Äôs coming out now, that captured your interest to begin with.

Guess what? You know how I said that when I first got interested in deep learning, around 2013-14, the only way to spin up on it was to trudge through miscellaneous research papers, YouTube videos, and blog posts ‚Äì and it was extremely frustrating and inefficient?

Well, that‚Äôs just kind of how it goes when you reach the cutting edge of a field ‚Äì and when you get to this "Stage 4," that‚Äôs what you can expect (at least, for now, until the field matures further).

That said, even when you're operating at the edge of human knowledge, there is still a way to optimize your approach.

I‚Äôll quote @ninja_maths, who recently posted about his own experience getting up to speed on his dissertation topic while doing a PhD in mathematics: https://t.co/9QVhXdrH8a

‚ÄúMy biggest mistake when starting my doctoral research was taking a top-down approach. I focused my efforts on a handful of research papers on the frontier of my chosen field, even writing code to solve problems in these papers from day one. However, I soon realized I lacked many foundational prerequisites, making the first year exceptionally tough.

What I should have done was spend 3-6 months dissecting the hell out of all the key research papers and books written on the subject, starting from the very basics (from my knowledge frontier) and working my way up (the bottom-up approach).‚Äù

I know ‚Äúcutting-edge‚Äù might sound like a single line where you cross from reading established textbooks to reading the latest arXiv preprint that blew up yesterday...

but in reality, the cutting edge is more of a ‚Äúzone‚Äù where the amount of guidance gradually fades. Just like how, on a physical knife, you typically see the blade start to narrow a couple millimeters before the true edge.

At the start of the cutting edge, there may not be any textbooks ‚Äì but there are typically miscellaneous guided resources like videos, blog posts, and foundational research papers and literature reviews that are easier to follow than the latest research papers all the way at the end of the cutting edge.

For a concrete example: if you want to work on cutting-edge LLM research, don‚Äôt start by immediately trying to build on the latest paper that‚Äôs come out.

Instead, start out with a literature search and collect the important papers, videos, blog posts, etc., that will bring you from the beginning of the edge of the field to the very end.

For instance, @karpathy's Neural Networks: Zero to Hero series on YouTube would stand firmly in that pool of resources: https://t.co/iMWY3HbslS

So would @jeremyphoward's From Deep Learning Foundations to Stable Diffusion: https://t.co/kUXv6jOdik

=== Closing Remarks ===

... Wow, this is by far the longest post that I've ever made on X. There's a lot more I want to say, and I would love to keep adding resources, but I have a mountain of code to write today and it's time to move on with the rest of my day.

If you know of any great resources that I missed, please do reply with them!

The resources I mentioned in this post are just off the top of my head, and I haven't done an extensive search, so it's quite possible (likely, even) that other great resources have popped up that I'm not aware of.

I would love to hear about them, and they would be super valuable to anyone reading this post, so please, suggest away.

P.S. Thanks to @tylerbruno05, @knivets, @iRammohanSharma, @shurensha, @Jordan__Adamson, @sidbing, and @DeGatchi for some great questions and interesting conversations recently that inspired me to write this post ‚Äì

and to @exojason for badgering me to start posting more about ML/AI, namely, the math underlying it and how to get up to speed with the field if you're starting from scratch.

Which reminds me... to anyone reading this post, feel free to reply with any follow-up questions about the math behind ML/AI or the learning process to catch up with the field. I'm always happy to answer questions, and that's typically when I do my best writing.

name: Andrej Karpathy
full_text:
@mrsiipa At one point a while back autoregressive language model papers were like that too. Formulating the joint likelihood, factorizing it, deriving the maximum likelihood estimate, discussing connections to Bayesian statistics and Convex Optimization,... 
Good example here:
note_tweet_text:
At one point a while back autoregressive language model papers were like that too. Formulating the joint likelihood, factorizing it, deriving the maximum likelihood estimate, discussing connections to Bayesian statistics and Convex Optimization,... 
Good example here:
https://t.co/TwLa4YhvfM

Then the engineers decided none of that was all that important outside of publishing the next ICML paper and now we mostly talk about predicting the next token in the sequence.

I expect diffusion will go through the same arc. Its roots are mathematically rigorous and have all kinds of connections but what you're doing at the end of the day is iterated denoising. Instead of going left to right as in autoregression. The more application builders get into the area the more acceptable it will become to talk about it simply, without the gatekeeping.

Not that the formalism is unimportant for making the next breakthrough but it's doing a disservice to the practitioners who are misled to think that it's somehow unapproachable.

name: Andrej Karpathy
full_text:
# RLHF is just barely RL

Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) is the third (and last) major stage of training an LLM, after pretraining and supervised finetuning (SFT). My rant on RLHF is that it is just barely RL, in a way that I think is not too widely https://t.co/sjRZvqc5KC
note_tweet_text:
# RLHF is just barely RL

Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) is the third (and last) major stage of training an LLM, after pretraining and supervised finetuning (SFT). My rant on RLHF is that it is just barely RL, in a way that I think is not too widely appreciated. RL is powerful. RLHF is not. Let's take a look at the example of AlphaGo. AlphaGo was trained with actual RL. The computer played games of Go and trained on rollouts that maximized the reward function (winning the game), eventually surpassing the best human players at Go. AlphaGo was not trained with RLHF. If it were, it would not have worked nearly as well. 

What would it look like to train AlphaGo with RLHF? Well first, you'd give human labelers two board states from Go, and ask them which one they like better:

Then you'd collect say 100,000 comparisons like this, and you'd train a "Reward Model" (RM) neural network to imitate this human "vibe check" of the board state. You'd train it to agree with the human judgement on average. Once we have a Reward Model vibe check, you run RL with respect to it, learning to play the moves that lead to good vibes. Clearly, this would not have led anywhere too interesting in Go. There are two fundamental, separate reasons for this:

1. The vibes could be misleading - this is not the actual reward (winning the game). This is a crappy proxy objective. But much worse,
2. You'd find that your RL optimization goes off rails as it quickly discovers board states that are adversarial examples to the Reward Model. Remember the RM is a massive neural net with billions of parameters imitating the vibe. There are board states are "out of distribution" to its training data, which are not actually good states, yet by chance they get a very high reward from the RM.

For the exact same reasons, sometimes I'm a bit surprised RLHF works for LLMs at all. The RM we train for LLMs is just a vibe check in the exact same way. It gives high scores to the kinds of assistant responses that human raters statistically seem to like. It's not the "actual" objective of correctly solving problems, it's a proxy objective of what looks good to humans. Second, you can't even run RLHF for too long because your model quickly learns to respond in ways that game the reward model. These predictions can look really weird, e.g. you'll see that your LLM Assistant starts to respond with something non-sensical like "The the the the the the" to many prompts. Which looks ridiculous to you but then you look at the RM vibe check and see that for some reason the RM thinks these look excellent. Your LLM found an adversarial example. It's out of domain w.r.t. the RM's training data, in an undefined territory. Yes you can mitigate this by repeatedly adding these specific examples into the training set, but you'll find other adversarial examples next time around. For this reason, you can't even run RLHF for too many steps of optimization. You do a few hundred/thousand steps and then you have to call it because your optimization will start to game the RM. This is not RL like AlphaGo was.

And yet, RLHF is a net helpful step of building an LLM Assistant. I think there's a few subtle reasons but my favorite one to point to is that through it, the LLM Assistant benefits from the generator-discriminator gap. That is, for many problem types, it is a significantly easier task for a human labeler to select the best of few candidate answers, instead of writing the ideal answer from scratch. A good example is a prompt like "Generate a poem about paperclips" or something like that. An average human labeler will struggle to write a good poem from scratch as an SFT example, but they could select a good looking poem given a few candidates. So RLHF is a kind of way to benefit from this gap of "easiness" of human supervision. There's a few other reasons, e.g. RLHF is also helpful in mitigating hallucinations because if the RM is a strong enough model to catch the LLM making stuff up during training, it can learn to penalize this with a low reward, teaching the model an aversion to risking factual knowledge when it's not sure. But a satisfying treatment of hallucinations and their mitigations is a whole different post so I digress. All to say that RLHF *is* net useful, but it's not RL.

No production-grade *actual* RL on an LLM has so far been convincingly achieved and demonstrated in an open domain, at scale. And intuitively, this is because getting actual rewards (i.e. the equivalent of win the game) is really difficult in the open-ended problem solving tasks. It's all fun and games in a closed, game-like environment like Go where the dynamics are constrained and the reward function is cheap to evaluate and impossible to game. But how do you give an objective reward for summarizing an article? Or answering a slightly ambiguous question about some pip install issue? Or telling a joke? Or re-writing some Java code to Python? Going towards this is not in principle impossible but it's also not trivial and it requires some creative thinking. But whoever convincingly cracks this problem will be able to run actual RL. The kind of RL that led to AlphaGo beating humans in Go. Except this LLM would have a real shot of beating humans in open-domain problem solving.

name: Florian Roth ‚ö°Ô∏è
full_text:
The problem isn‚Äôt that the update was malformed.
The problem isn‚Äôt that the validator they wrote didn‚Äôt catch the error before it was deployed.

The real problem is that they didn‚Äôt have any canary system to which they deployed the update before rolling it out to millions of https://t.co/Ol2fvgqc0s
note_tweet_text:
The problem isn‚Äôt that the update was malformed.
The problem isn‚Äôt that the validator they wrote didn‚Äôt catch the error before it was deployed.

The real problem is that they didn‚Äôt have any canary system to which they deployed the update before rolling it out to millions of endpoints all at once.

Since no external factors ‚Äî like the driver of another vendor (see the Kaspersky issue with Intel drivers years ago) ‚Äî were involved, a single $400 canary machine could have prevented this disaster. The absence of such a machine and a staged rollout could be interpreted as gross negligence in court, and that‚Äôs why everyone at CrowdStrike is worried.

Mistakes and slips are human. No one would be angry about that. But having only a simple and possibly flawed validator between an analyst and a kernel driver on millions of systems worldwide could be seen as grossly negligent.

It‚Äôs the only thing that matters. Everything else they describe, added to their testing, and improved processes is just filler, possibly to distract from the one relevant fact.

name: Taelin
full_text:
Something might be really wrong - because it works.

By merely enumerating terms, you can find "new algorithms". For example, if you try to solve for `f` in `f 0010 = 1010 && f 1100 = 0010`, you will quickly find the optimal binary increment algorithm. It is the first match. Even https://t.co/5Mt81X64ZG
note_tweet_text:
Something might be really wrong - because it works.

By merely enumerating terms, you can find "new algorithms". For example, if you try to solve for `f` in `f 0010 = 1010 && f 1100 = 0010`, you will quickly find the optimal binary increment algorithm. It is the first match. Even with no pruning, it just works.

And this is just the baseline - I'm talking about a very dumb Haskell enumerator using the Omega Monad. You can go ahead, implement and see it yourself. Now, once you add dependent types and prune the search space a little bit through some obvious constraints (like not creating >2 layers of constructors), you can easily find more complex algorithms, like QuickSort.

Now, things start getting really interesting once you optimize it for an optimal evaluator. SUP nodes can be used to share computations across attempts, and scopeless lambdas allow you to pass HOAS contexts around the generator. And, by applying the equality directly to superposed terms, it will magically prune out entire spaces that will not lead to a solution. Again, nothing fancy - just the obvious optimizations we know very well.

The result is: we can actually just find stuff. Like, we just can. I'll stop using the AGI term, because it became a meme at this point, and is unrelated. Yet, when it comes to inventing *new science* or discovering *new mathematics*, for all I can tell, we can actually just brute-force find the proofs we want. This has nothing to do with reasoning or "AI". It is a dumb brick that just outputs what you'd expect an intelligent agent to be needed for. It just isn't?

Perhaps I'm being really naive and an exponential wall is about to humble (and embarrass) me. This is so obvious I seriously can't be the first one to be trying this, right? Right?? Yet, for all I can tell, everything I've done went exactly as I think it should.

I'm frustrated because I have so many other stuff to do (series A, pitches, gamedev company, home stuff, health). All I want to do is keep exploring and see where this goes

name: Mira
full_text:
They have no hope of solving it because there is no alignment problem.

It's phrased like there's a specific problem to solve, but there isn't.
In full generality("ideal agent in arbitrary environment"), the problem is provably impossible("Rice's theorem", etc.)
And there's no
note_tweet_text:
They have no hope of solving it because there is no alignment problem.

It's phrased like there's a specific problem to solve, but there isn't.
In full generality("ideal agent in arbitrary environment"), the problem is provably impossible("Rice's theorem", etc.)
And there's no specific computational model more restricted than "arbitrary turing machines" that you might solve it relative to.

It's not like you can prove a theorem or construct a mathematical object or produce an algorithm(solving a specific problem, not "constructing an aligned AGI"). There's no "alignment problem" for much the same reason there's no 10,000th busy beaver number: You don't know when to stop counting.

It's all too conceptual and rhetorical. The AI labs are at least trying and read the important papers. DeepMind makes earnest attempts to do good research.

For the longest time, I didn't think that EA types even took alignment seriously because they weren't registering to me as even trying.
They have money, they have people, they're not "dumb", but they also aren't doing anything that somebody that's worried about AI complexity issues would be trying to do. It's always Google DeepMind or random university CS professors studying algorithms and limits and bounds and stuff. Never an EA. Always caught in rhetorical games and never building the skill of developing a math field or similar.

So I don't think they'll ever be happy, but it's because they don't know what they want. They're treating rhetoric as the goal and realizing it won't ever go anywhere. And that's true: AI labs or EAs or anyone will never solve alignment, because there's no alignment problem to solve.
